		<username>B. Caesar Cubillos (CubeJack@aol.com)</username>
		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>What the heck did I just watch?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I saw this movie for free at the local premiere along with a packed theater. The movie starts out very strong and draws the audience in immediately. I was very intrigued to see more, the plot seemed interesting and began to lure the audience in more when Nicolas Cage reached the island of Summersisle and threw even more twists. Then suddenly the plot went completely haywire and the movie turned into a spoof. The comic relief was witty at first, then took over the movie and turned into an unintentional laughfest. I found myself laughing more at this than I did at some comedy movies that I've seen! First off, this movie is NOT a horror film. I'm tired of these movies being advertised to appear as horror only to disappoint the viewer. This usually is reserved for M. Night Shyamalan films, but now appears to have expanded to others. The film is never scary a single time. Are these advertisers doing this on purpose in order to get money from the fans of the horror genre? Was Cage's dialogue SUPPOSED to be so funny? Toward the end when he's being hauled off by the island residents he begins screaming like a madman and tossing out comments that made the entire audience erupt in laughter. When he snapped earlier and began punching out female islanders the movie seemed to lose control. He even has a fistfight with one that should have lasted about 2 seconds, but instead was turned into a drawn out scene. What was even more hilarious was watching the woman he'd just knocked unconscious begin to overact and have wild facial expressions. I began to wonder if William Shatner had helped coach the actors.This movie was worthy of Mystery Science Theater 3000. I felt almost betrayed. I was actually drawn to care about the lead character before the script seemed to run out of ideas and drop dead. Why were so many plot lines given that went nowhere? This movie had more dead ends than a ghost town. Was there any point to the whole bee analogy? The opening scene was great, but what the heck did it have to do with the rest of the movie? It made no sense at all! Why was the teacher given some odd twin that served no purpose? What was the deal with the old woman twins who talked in unison the entire time? Why did they keep going back to the stupid cell phone that had no service, and why did they have it ring toward the end? Did they just need to fill time? Toward the end why was Ellen Burnstyn painted up like Mel Gibson in Braveheart? I kept waiting for her to shout "FREEDOM!" Finally, when they showed what the wicker man really was I wanted to faint. It looked like a Lego Wishnick Troll. I couldn't believe how fast this movie had deteriorated into a b-grade comedy. By the time the women were all chanting "The drone must die" I wanted to die myself. What a ridiculous and unintentionally funny scene.For your own sake, skip this movie! I saw it for free and even I felt ripped off. If you really feel that you have to see it, wait for it to be on cable or borrow the DVD from some Nicolas Cage fan.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>Although the sets were beautiful and interesting, and the locale lush and serene, the rest of the movie just stunk. It's really too bad - the plot starts off intriguing, but early on you feel as though there's just ... something missing somehow, and that's usually a bad sign. I kept waiting for this movie to save itself somehow, but it all just became too predictable, and there wasn't enough done to paint the 'baddies' of the film in a truly menacing or deeply sinister light, surprising indeed given what the actual plot turns out to be -- I never really felt intimidated by them; I just thought they were odd.It wasn't the fault of the actors or actresses who all gave wonderful performances (although Nicolas Cage is somewhat controversial in this regard according to the forums for this film, I have always enjoyed watching him, though this one wasn't one of his best films). Instead, I lay blame to the screenwriter and the editor - sometimes no matter how much talent you have working on a project, if an editor pieces a film together poorly, there's nothing that can save it, and that's what seems to have happened in this case, which also explains why viewers feel much is missing from the film.It's worth a look on DVD, perhaps, at least because the plot is somewhat interesting for a good part of the movie. Ultimately, though, save your cash and stay far away from this stinker. Why oh why can't someone make a truly great horror / suspense film anymore??</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2014-11-01</date>
		<username>Edward Goldenberg</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>One Of The Funniest Movies Of 2006.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>A sheriff investigating the disappearance of a young girl from a small island discovers there's a larger mystery to solve among the island's secretive, neo-pagan community.Although The Wicker Man was intended to be a serious horror film, through sloppy directing and acting, it came off not scary at all and more as a comedy. The Wicker Man is comedic gold, it's one of the funniest movies of 2006, although it's a pity that it wasn't intended to be a comedy, had it been intended to be a comedy, then it probably would have been a smash hit. Everything from Nicholas Cage's over the top performance to the script has got loads of laughs in it. All throughout the course of the movie, I kept saying things like: "This is supposed to be scary?" or "This is supposed to be a horror movie?" Because judging from all of the unintentionally hysterical moments that occurred in this movie, I honestly believe that they made a mistake by marketing this movie as a horror movie. However, the unintentional hilarious values do make this movie worth watching, although it's not good as a horror movie, it does succeed at being an unintentional comedy. Want a good comedy? Simply watch this movie, you'll get your laughs out of it.Hands down, Nicholas Cage did the best acting in the film, as far as the laughs went. One scene in particular, he asks Kate Beahan about a doll: "How'd it get burned? How it get burned?! HOW'D IT GET BURNED?! HOW'D IT GET BURNED?!" She replies: "I DON'T KNOW!" Then there is a hilarious scene in which Cage goes around punching women in a bear suit, and it all cumulates with the infamous: "NOT THE BEES!" Scene. I have never seen Nicholas Cage overact so much before in any movie. Then again, I wouldn't be surprised if he knew that this movie was going to be bad, and so he decided to overact on purpose. However, I do give praise to Nicholas Cage for his results in bringing out comedy, which he definitely succeeds in doing, too bad that the movie was supposed to be a horror movie. And not to mention that Neil LaBute did a bad job with the directing and the screen writing, but the way he handles the unintentional funny stuff, priceless.If you decide to watch this remake of the original 1970's movie, then don't watch it expecting it to be a scary movie, as it is anything but that. Instead, when you watch it, you should be expecting to see it as something along the lines of an unintentional comedy. On a scale from one to ten with one being the absolute worst and ten being the absolute best, I'll give this movie a rating of five stars. That rating means that this movie is half and half, it gets no stars for being a horror movie, but it gets five stars for being an unintentional comedy. So if you do decide to give this movie ago, then all I can say is this: be prepared to laugh, because the way that most of the scenes are handled is so overdone, that you won't find them scary or frightening, you will find them laughable.5/10</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>TheMarwood</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>A ham sandwich with extra cheese</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This updated Wicker Man is mostly entertaining misguided nonsense for a good portion of its running time, before going completely off the rails by the finale. Nic Cage goes to a small mysterious island in search of a missing girl, where some truly ham fisted plotting and dialogue play out as this island of mostly women give him the runaround. Leelee Sobieski is introduced as she sinisterly bites into an apple and that's about as nuanced and subtle as any performances get here. There's plenty of laughs with some truly bizarre plot detours and Nic Cage loosing his cool with these women. Neil LaBute is an odd choice to write and direct this material and the results are insanely loopy. The last act ups the bizarre and truly is a sight to behold. From the absurd image of a woman sitting in a room wearing a beard of bees, to Ellen Burstyn prancing about with half her face painted blue, The Wicker Man turns into a show stopping display of incompetent filmmaking and camp. The truncated theatrical version omits the now famous "not the bees!" bit and a quick scene of torture that certainly gets some laughs, but has a tacked on ending 'six months later' that is thankfully deleted in the extended version. No film with Cage dressed in a bear costume kicking the crap out of a bunch of crazed women should be considered a film with no merit.</fullReview>

That this film was intended as a comedy.Unless you can stand much of the film's running time to see Nic Cage at the edge of losing his career to a scene where he runs around in a bear suit, THE WICKER MAN is a remake that proves that all is well when you leave well enough alone.Rating: *1/2 out of 5.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>It needs it for this one, I think a 1 out of 10 is too generous. At the end, just break out, dammit, it's only f_ckin' wicker! His arms didn't look broken to me. Just spread open the damn wicker bars. Sure, you'd fall to your death probably, but that would have been a tad more merciful that what happened to you. And you'd have screwed up the pagan witches' plan a wee bit. When you've (finally) reached the conclusion that these people of capable of sacrificing a little girl, then you realize that it's really going to be you, one should pull out all the stops immediately, and not wait for them to grab you. 	<review>
		<date>2007-10-06</date>
		<username>slayrrr666 (slayrrr666@yahoo.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Disappointing and unspectacular remake</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"The Wicker Man" is an incredibly flawed and uninspiring remake.**SPOILERS**Haunted by a tragic accident, Detective Edward Malus, (Nicholas Cage) leaves the police force to comprehend the tragedy. Sent a letter by his ex Willow Woodward, (Kate Beahan) she claims her daughter Rowan, (Erika-Shaye Gair) is missing and asks him to come investigate. Arriving on the isolated Summers Isle, the habitants' strange rituals and ceremonies start to infuriate him. Not getting anywhere in the investigation, as every lead turns out false, he begins to get more irritated and tries harder than ever to solve the case. After finally finding a real clue, he sets off and manages to see what the real reason was for the ceremony, which haunts him to his very soul.The Good News: This gets very little right. One of them is that the opening really works for the film. The everyday normality it opens to is expertly shattered with a brutal and shocking crash, and the eventual race before the fire burns everything is handled with some nice amounts of suspense. This has a really good tendency to stick to quick shots of whatever to derive it's scares, and several work. Opening a room where one is covered with bees or looking down to discover a dead victim are such examples of this. The search at times can be quite fun, as there's some really good scenes in here that are derived from that. It gets considerably more so towards the end, and especially after the sequence where he gets stuck in the underground cavern. That is a nicely suspenseful scene, and along with the others, constitutes the film's only good points.The Bad News: This has a few considerable flaws going for it. One of them is that there's way too much insistence on the aforementioned jump cuts. There's a large amount of them, and while some work for their visual impact or shock effect, they're at most really a distraction. There's so many that it can become blasé after a point. It can become deadening if there's too many of them, which this one has. There's even a problem with the way the investigation is handled. At the very end, he starts going around and throwing his weight around to make up for all the lies that were told to him. This really seems like an act which should've been done sooner, especially after the reception received. It might've worked better and had better results if done somewhat sooner. Another pretty big flaw is that there's no real surprises to be had from this. It plays out exactly as it originally did, and all the surprises and fun to be had from that one are gone because it is so familiar. Even the plot twist doesn't surprise, which is the greatest flaw in the film. This is built up to a twist that has none of the fear and dread that it featured in the original, and since there's a lot of talk about what's going to happen before it gets there, it effectively ruins all the momentum it would've had going into it the same. Even the tagged-on epilogue is a failure, as the movie should've ended with the twist rather than the lame gag given here. These here all keep the film down considerably.The Final Verdict: While not a complete waste of time, this one isn't that spectacular and doesn't even come close to the iconic original. That leaves this one mainly for those who tend to enjoy these harmless remakes only, while hardcore horror fans are urged to use extreme caution with it.Rated PG-13: Language and Violence</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2007-01-29</date>
		<username>José Luis Rivera Mendoza (jluis1984)</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>A wasted opportunity...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Robin Hardy's 1973 cult film, "The Wicker Man", is definitely one of the most interesting films ever made, and one of the best horror movies in cinema history. Written by Anthony Shaffer, it is a film that through a thrilling story of mystery and suspense, raised interesting questions about faith, philosophy and human psychology. The clashes between extreme ideologies and its disastrous consequences were the main theme of the film, and its eerie atmosphere, ambiguous subject and original score turned the movie into a revered cult classic. To remake a movie like "The Wicker Man" is definitely not an easy task, but certainly a very interesting project to make, as the source offered countless possibilities to explore. Director and writer Neil LaBute, famed for the interesting takes on human nature he makes in his films and plays, seemed like an ideal choice to make a reinvention of a classic, but sadly, I must say that this project ended up as another wasted opportunity.In this version, Edward Malus (Nicholas Cage) is a Californian patrolman taking some days off as he is recovering from the shock of a tragic accident on the road. While recovering, Malus receives a letter from his former fianceé Willow (Kate Beahan), telling him that her daughter has disappeared and asking him for help. Confused about the fact that Willow has contacted him after she left him many years ago, Malus decides to travel to the private island of Summersisle, where Willow lives now as a member of a community dedicated to the production of honey. In the island, Malus starts the investigations, but the population is suspiciously very uncooperative and of a very strange behavior. Soon Edward discovers that Rowan is kept hidden in the island and that there is something bigger going on in Summersile.Neil LaBute's take on the original is certainly a bold spin on the themes: instead of religion being the main theme, LaBute makes extreme sexism the focus of the movie. Under this theme, Summersile is now a matriarchy where females rule and males are oppressed, and the film's "hero" is an unbalanced man with a deep disdain for females. In all fairness, it is an interesting and ambitious spin, and it's clear that LaBute really understood that "The Wicker Man" was more than the tale of a missing kid; however, he fails to develop this subtext through the story and ends up with a very weak background to the core plot, leaving his "Wicker Man" as just another typical thriller. While on previous occasions LaBute has successfully pulled off interesting takes on the many forms of sexism, his work on "The Wicker Man" feels really weak, and ultimately disappointing.Unlike his writing, his direction of the movie is effective and during the first part of the movie, almost matches the original in terms of atmospheric horror and overall eeriness. Sadly, it takes an enormous effort to transform a lousy script into a good movie, and LaBute simply can't make it this time. While the movie moves at a nice pace and has some very good cinematography, the problems of the script become quickly too apparent and by the second half the movie becomes a series of well-directed scenes that have not logic or serve no purpose. LaBute is a good director, but the badly developed script finally damages the whole movie and good talent gets wasted with lousy dialogs and silly situations. Nicholas Cage's performance as Edward Malus is probably one of the worst roles of his career, and not really because his performance is completely bad, but because the character is horribly written. Ellen Burstyn is another wasted talent as Sister Summersile, the matriarch of the island and main "antagonist" of the film. Burstyn delivers her lines with dignity, but as Cage, can't do much to save a script doomed since its conception. Kate Beahan is definitely the worst actress of the cast, making her character look even worse than what it is (an accomplishment in itself, as Willow is one of the worst written ones). Leelee Sobieski appears in a completely unnecessary (and underused) role and definitely only Molly Parker escapes untainted by the film.In the end, the debacle of "The Wicker Man" can be summarized in two words: bad script. LaBute's idea of using sexism as main theme is good and quite original, but he betrays the original's spirit (and in many ways LaBute's own ideas) by the oversimplification of the characters. While Sister Summersile becomes the embodiment of evil, officer Malus appears as a weak and naive man, taking out the whole clash of believes from the picture in favor of cheap sympathies for the character. This change proves to be a mistake as Malus victimization becomes a joke that in the end makes the whole finale feel utterly pointless. The many plot holes and silly lines of dialog are just the tip of the iceberg of a doomed screenplay.In the end, "The Wicker Man" is a horrible disappointment, not only to fans of the original, but also to fans of Neil LaBute, as the movie is nowhere near his previous success and feels as a cheap made for TV thriller. I'm not against remakes, as I like to see different versions of a story, but this update to "The Wicker Man" is a movie to be left forgotten as soon as possible. True, it's good looking trash, but trash after all. 8/10</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Well, what to say...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I'm not a movie critic, don't pupport to be and don't aspire to be. However, what i will say is i like movies, REAL movies, with real stories, real plot-lines, and real actors. The original Wicker Man is all of these things. Any remake of an original classic, possibly 'cult' film will never EVER come close to capturing the feeling of the first and best original. Why does Hollywood feel the need to to try and recapture something which cannot possibly be re-captured? Easy money? Riding on the back of previous winners? Who knows. All i know is, leave the originals alone. Promote them, re-release them, whatever. Just never, EVER re-make them. True movie lovers who know and appreciate the originals will scythe you down. And the general movie-going public will listen to what the seasoned film lover says. And even if they don't, they have eyes. If they liked or dis-liked the re-make, they will search out the original and be astounded at how wrong film-makers now-adays can ruin what is a truly awesome film (and I'm generalising, not talking about this film in particular.) Hope this helps? :o)</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Oh no not The Wicker Man!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Upon my unfortunate viewing of this abomination known as "The Wicker Man," It had been foretold, at least in my perspective, that this was a film of great unintentional humor; the kind of film that one partakes in laughing their jolly mouths off at the utter ridiculousness of the movie. However after seeing this trash known as "The Wicker Man" I recall my reaction to the film to be most horrified. This wretchedness might be the worst film I have ever seen in my life, and I shall tell you why.Firstly the writing in this flick is some of the most pointless and appalling dialogue I ever heard. There are many examples of useless dialogue exchanged from character to character, and yet it never is related to the story material at hand. Plus, along with the dialogue, there are multiple scenes in the film that NEVER serve any purpose to the story whatsoever. For instance at the beginning while Cage is patrolling on his motorcycle, he retrieves a doll to a family who is moving out of state. While he carries on to return the doll, a big rig literally drives through the car where the family is parked and kills them, just like that, and yet there is no mentioning of the incident again! Now you could make the argument that the wreck later haunted his dreams throughout the film, but why did it have to be a wreck, and couldn't his fear for his missing daughter be a better nightmare fuel? To say that there is a great immense of under acting in his role is an understatement. Nicolas Cage is CLEARLY winging this thing like its a huge pile of nothing (can't blame him.) Plus it does not help that his character has, well, NO CHARACTER! In fact every role in this film is under developed and under acted, which leads to a band of misfits that you care less about than a Facebook update about your sister's "girls night out." But most importantly the film is the very definition of jumbled. It seems like the film is trying to portray it's story, but it chooses pointless and out-of-context scenes to do so. The entire structure is deeply flawed. In conclusion, The Wicker Man is a dreadfully disarranged film of a story that takes us nowhere, acting that makes the mortuary service at Ben Stein's funeral look exciting, and a terribly misguided directorial job that could not simply handle the material at hand. 		<shortDescription>"How did it get produced? How did it get produced!!1?"</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>You probably know "The Wicker Man" remake, even if you haven't seen it completely. After all, this is the age of the internet, where every so-called "fail" makes it to Youtube ? and few films have failed harder than "The Wicker Man".We don't know what led director Neil LaBute to the realization that he was the man to remake one of the most iconic horror-films of all times. However, I'm tempted to believe that he must have been pondering the options to remake either "The Wicker Man" or "The Rocky Horror Picture Show". Possibly consuming a ham-sandwich at this time, he opted to cast Nicolas Cage as protagonist either which way. Or maybe he flipped a coin, imagining Cate Blanchett as Riff Raff, in case the decision fell on RHPC (which would have been produced without a soundtrack, by the way). But the coin fell on "The Wicker Man" side.So he went on to produce "The Wicker Man", took out all the elements that made the original brilliant, instead filling it with putrid acting, one of the most improbable storyline in cinema's history and plenty (unintentional) humor."The Wicker Man" would have deserved to become a flop and an obscure footnote in cinema history. However, the gods of cinema must have been as little amused as the fans and bestowed a fate much worst on the remake. It became a cinematic joke: a testament to the inability of a director and evidence that Cage had spent all his talent in "Leaving Las Vegas", all that's left of him being an empty, grimacing shell of an actor. Like John Tavolta's "Battlefield Earth" and the latest works of M. Night Shyamalan, it became an epitome of fail and the butt of jokes on many mocking, fan-made Youtube-videos.Sure I recommend that people and especially the fans of the one-and-only "Wicker Man" watch this train-wreck of a movie. Watch it and have a good laugh at the expense of everybody involved. Make it a "Rocky Horror Picture Show"-like event and when Cage holds up a charred dolls to the screen, screeching "how did it get burned?", reply whole-heartedly: "With fire!!!" It get's the same number of points that a remake of "The Rocky Horror Picture Show" as supernatural thriller, featuring Nicolas Cage as Frank N. Furter (and without music) would have gotten ? plus the mandatory point from IMDb.</fullReview>

		<date>2013-06-06</date>
		<username>Oskari Ratinen</username>
		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>Quite possibly the worst remake ever</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It was my intention to review this title as an independent film and avoid mentioning the original. It's impossible, because much of the mental and physical pain this movie causes somehow traces back to the fact that it's supposed to be a "remake".Remakes are usually not a very good idea in general. You really need to have a new perspective on the story to justify a remake. If you bring something new to the table while holding true to the original version, then you've succeeded, whether or not the quality of your work compares to the original.The world and story of the original Wicker Man were so well thought of that virtually no logical inconsistencies remain in the movie. The world view and the way of thinking of a heathen culture and their collision with the Christian values is plausibly depicted from the beginning to the end, and in the end no questions remain. All the characters and their motives are treated with equal consideration and respect. The end result is as much a study on religion in general as it is a movie. There are several perspectives to choose from, and whichever you choose, you can still relate to the movie and agree that it's a fine piece of work.To bring something new to that is a gigantic task and should only be attempted after a very critical evaluation of the idea you have for the remake. But here, there is no perspective whatsoever. There's just a horrible mishmash of poorly executed direct loans from the original, and erratic changes for whatever god awful reason. Honestly, I don't have a clue what they were thinking. It's like they threw away the consideration, consistency and plausibility of the original, made an 8-year old rewrite the script and brought in Nicholas Cage to punch (and kick) women in the face.Now, I wholeheartedly agree that violence towards women can be an element in a film, but just like any other form of violence, it needs to make sense from the viewpoint of the story. The character doing it needs to have a reason for behaving violently, and we the viewers need to know what that reason is. Nicholas Cage delivers the punches, but he doesn't deliver the reasons for them, or any other sort of emotion for that matter. When his character finds out that he is in fact a father and his daughter is in grave danger, he reacts as if someone just told him that the price of a beer just went up by 5 cents in the bar around the corner. Tommy Wiseau's performance in "The Room" is more vivid and plausible. I'm 100% serious about this.Everything that's remotely good about this sorry excuse of a "remake" comes straight from the original, and even that means individual lines of dialogue and not much more. Every single change that has been made is disastrous or worse. The soul and spirit of the original movie has been brutalized, and they still dare call this a remake.If I had never ever even heard that the original existed, I might, just might have given this 2/10, because then I would've been fooled into thinking that they had a pretty original idea that they just miserably failed to execute. The acting is horrible, the directing is horrible, the production is horrible, everything about this movie is horrible and appalling and will haunt me to my grave and beyond. Avoid like the plague.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2008-02-27</date>
		<username>D_Burke</username>
		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>One of 2006's Biggest Disappointments; Could Have Been Much Better</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>A lot of people were disappointed with this movie who hadn't actually seen the original film. After all, you have an otherwise good director, Neil Labute, who made other brilliant films such as "Nurse Betty" and "Your Friends and Neighbors", and you had Academy Award winners Nicholas Cage and Ellen Burstyn. Plus, Burstyn was brilliant in the best horror film of all time, "The Exorcist" (1973). With this impressive roster of talent (and that's not even the whole list), this remake should have been really good.For people who had seen the original movie, like me, this remake came as an even larger disappointment. After all, the original 1973 film was a brilliant movie. The reason it was so scary was because there could easily have been a separate island like Summerisle in real life, and human sacrifices could, and probably do, still take place in some countries. However, if the original movie had weaknesses, it was in the surprising number of plot holes that could have been explained but weren't. Going into this movie, I thought if the American remake would do anything right, it would at least patch up some of those plot holes.Needless to say, for every plot hole the American remake tried to cover up, at least two more opened up in the form of faulty logic and further unexplained events. For instance, why were there twins on the island? And if there was no electricity on the island, how did Summerisle have their own web page? Why didn't the male inhabitants ever talk? And last but not least, what was the significance of the car crash in the beginning of the film which supposedly cost the life of the jaded girl in the car? Those are just a few of the events that remained unexplained even after the film's conclusion.Additionally, Nicholas Cage's character didn't seem to be very logical himself. In a failed attempt to make this film into a suspense/action thriller, they had him do stupid things like diving into water to retrieve a body that's obviously dead, or wandering into a dark barn when he thinks he heard someone wandering around. Cage's character lacks both healthy fear and common sense, and it makes this film unintentionally campy.Without giving too much away, the ending was surprisingly disappointing as well. All I will say is that it ended in a similar fashion to the original, which is good because I initially thought it would have a happy, cop-out ending. But the #1 thing that made the original Wicker Man ending scary was absolutely ignored in this movie. The original ending to the 1973 movie was made scarier because of the townspeople's reaction to the Wicker Man burning. In this movie, they seem far more jaded, and the scary effect doesn't work at all.In fact, this movie was so flawed, that when I went to see it opening weekend at the movie theater, the audience was laughing all the way through it. It's unfortunate too, because you can't take this movie seriously when Cage punches a woman in the face, then steals her bear suit. This movie has proved itself to be more unintentionally funny than "Mommie Dearest".This version of "The Wicker Man" could have been a whole lot better in so many ways. It's unfortunate too, because I really like Nicholas Cage. If you don't want to be too disappointed, see the original "Wicker Man" first. The plus side to this movie coming out is that the original is no longer so hard to find on DVD. Now you can find that version in most stores. As for this version, well, I think most of the people involved in making this film know how much better they could have done.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2007-07-24</date>
		<username>fortey</username>
		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>Nic Cage comedies rule</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This was pretty much a horrible film, but that is neither here nor there. This movie demands to be watched for having some of the most earnest, unintentional, hilarious comedy I have ever seen. I can only assume the jokes were unintentional, but whatever the case I was rolling. Allow me to share some highlights.- Nic Cage, at home, disturbed, moody and medicated, gets a mysterious letter from his ex written with some amazing calligraphy. And then a phone call. He answers "Hello?" but there is silence...and then...and then...wait for it...dial tone! Nic lunges away from the phone as though the devil himself were giving him a wet willy. Lord, that dial tone is frightening.- Nic discovers a burnt doll in a grave. But...how'd it get burned? How'd it get burned? How'ditgetburned? HOW'DITGETBURNED?!?!?!?!?! -Desperately searching for Ellen Burstyn, Nic Cage ransacks her home. As you might expect of Ellen Burstyn, she has a room where a one eyed old man covered in creepy bumps and bee stings sits shirtless in a bed.-But wait! It's not just one eyed old men. It's naked girls covered in bees. For some reason.-Dressed in a full body bear costume, Nicolas Cage (filmed in a nice long shot) runs straight up a hill while the entire population of the island watches, and punches out some random woman. And he's dressed as a bear.- Fed up with the island's insanity, and fresh from punching out a woman (not the aforementioned woman on a hill) Nic is attacked by Leelee Sobieski. After a brief scuffle, it becomes clear what Nic Cage must do. He must kung-fu kick her right into a wall.-The children of the island are little liars. You little liars. And your teacher is the biggest liar of all. And who the hell put a bird in that desk? Why would you do something sick like that???? -Killing Nicolas Cage will not bring back your goddamn honey harvest.-Nic Cage hates it when you smash his legs. Or whatever you do to them off screen. He hates is so bad he'll scream about it long and hard.-Man, there are a lot of beekeepers on this island.-When Nic Cage gets bored on a dock, then sees a body under the dock, he will channel the same kung-fu he uses to beat down Leelee Sobieski and do some manner of US Olympic gymnastics team flip right into the water.-Little girls chanting "phallic symbol phallic symbol" is so funny,even Nic Cage, possibly struggling to believe he's in this movie, will laugh at it.-For no reason that will ever be explained, upon arriving on the island, the first thing someone does is steal Nic Cage's self-help "Everything's OK" book on tape.-Nic Cage will steal your bicycle at gunpoint if he has to. So you better step away from the bike.-Nic Cage is not above screaming the word "bitches" repeatedly. Because he knows you'll get the message soon enough. Probably.In short, this movie is like a Mel Brook's production of old. This is comedy gold. Love it. Love it!!</fullReview>

		<date>2012-04-10</date>
		<username>mail_kobben</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Underestimated</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Contains some spoilers. Be warned.My first review. This movie deserves a much higher score and I'm going to try and explain why. Hitchcock said something like "I like to scare people and while making them smile". That is exactly what this movie does. It has mysticism that builds up while also getting more and more comical and not in a slap-stick sort of way, but in a subtle, absurd one, which is my favorite kind of humor. It's not funny if you know it's for fun. If you feel the same way, you'll enjoy this movie.I just love "my god? Oh, my GOD!" when Cage is introduced to the wooden statue and "NOT THE BEES!" and all the slapping and the bear costume. That and the thick mystic atmosphere makes a lovely recipe of a movie if you ask me. A mixing of genres. It is not a thriller and it is not a comedy, it's something rare which is both engaging and comic.I've read some of the reviews here and would like to address the issue people tend to have on Cage's acting. I though it was superb. One must have in mind that his character is suffering from lots of trauma and medication and that it is a rare genre. Despite this I though his character was deep and dynamic, with lots of layers that might confuse people expecting a B-thriller and one-dimensional leads. I love the way he approaches Willow that I think every hurt/love-sick man can identify with. Lots of layers there. Impressive. One must also consider the fact that he is not a "good guy", but a just a man with issues and possibly quite anti-feminist.Don't have much to add to the other actors, but would like to point out that they are not bad actors, but are portraying complex characters and seen from Cage's perspective, whom himself is delusional and mentally ill and it all adds to the mysticism and they're all doing a good job.I think the problem many people have with this movie and its characters is that it enters an alien world with alien people in it. You need someone to cling on to and that would be Cage. Only problem is that he turns even worse than the others? I on the other hand like it and want to see more of it.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2010-09-03</date>
		<username>Tweekums</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>An unnecessary remake</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The original version of 'The Wicker Man' has become a cult classic but I don't think this remake has any chance of achieving such a status, gone is the constant sense than something is very wrong and in its place is a bunch of slightly strange women. Whereas Edward Woodward portrayed a devout police sergeant looking for a missing girl he is unconnected to Nicolas Cage plays a policeman who has received a letter from his former fiancée claiming that her daughter has gone missing making his task a personal matter.Before receiving the letter he is involved in a strange accident where he tries to rescue a young girl and her mother from a burning car; he fails but strangely no bodies are found. Once he hears from his ex he heads to the mysterious Summer's Isle in Puget Sound. Here he finds a less than warm welcome from the islands women and silence from the men. As he investigates everybody denies any knowledge of the missing girl but when he finds evidence of her existence he is told that she died. He starts to suspect that she was sacrificed as part of the island's harvest rituals but when he finds no body in her supposed grave he believes that she is still alive but being kept hidden for this years sacrifice. As the time of the ritual he searches everywhere for her and eventually finds her only to learn the terrifying truth about why he was invited to the island.I wouldn't say this was a terrible film; it passed the time well enough and I wasn't bored, unfortunately I didn't find it particularly scary either which is a bit of a weakness in a horror film. Nicolas Cage is a decent actor but his portrayal of the policeman wasn't a patch on Edward Woodward's. This may be down to the changes in the story that made the character far less innocent. There are some nice touches; I liked how Nicolas Cage's character was called Edward and is ex-fiancée's surname was Woodward in a nod to the star of the original and the 'stand away from the bicycle' scene earned a laugh.Overall I wouldn't recommend going out of ones way to see this but if it is on television it passes the time well enough and even provides some unintentional laughs. If you are thinking of buying 'The Wicker Man' on DVD I'd get the 1973 original though.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>The Hilarity!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I rate this a 2 out of 10 because this movie in no way lived up to its promises of of thrills, scares, and intrigue. This movie took itself so seriously that the unintentional humor in it gave me stitches from laughing so hard. I had some friends watch it with me and they all swore that they never laughed so hard in their lives. 		<date>2006-09-07</date>
		<username>disneybliss-1</username>
		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>Yes it's a bad movie, this review is focused on why</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I didn't realize until reading one of the other viewer's reviews that this was a remake. Having said that, upon watching the movie, I immediately recognized that LaBute was striving for that 1970s genre that I enjoyed so much growing up. Other movies in this genre, that I grew up watching annually on TV, to give you an idea were THE PEOPLE, THE SPELL, AUDREY ROSE, THE REINCARNATION OF PETER PROUD, and there was one with Leonard Nimoy, BAFFLED! and another, the name escapes me about a woman in a new town, but she's having reoccurring dreams of having been tortured as a Salem witch.But the problem with Neil LaBute's THE WICKER MAN is all in the writing and editing.I don't agree with the other reviews about the acting. I have my master's in acting and I believe myself to be a pretty critical judge in that department. The acting only looked bad because of what they had to work with. But everyone was fine, everyone except the actress who played Willow. I thought she was very poor. And I was distracted by her lips which looked overly injected with collagen. However Nick Cage, Ellen Burstyn, Leelee Sobieski and the actresses who played Sisters Beech and Rose were all very good. They have no control over the words and the editing,--and the directing--and that's wherein the problem lies.I thought about the movie afterward and decided that the movie would have been fine if two actions had been done: 1. completely taken out the whole mother-daughter car scene in the beginning, and all the hallucinations with those characters throughout the movie.Between trying to figure out the meaning of the missing bodies in that car, and watching Nick Cage pop pills and seeing those people over and over in his present reality, AND relive the car scene over and over, I was sure that that experience and those characters were going to have to come back in the movie sometime, and they did not.and 2. fixed the choppy editing. One minute Nick Cage is running here, then he's running there, then he's under water, then he's running through Sister Summerisle's house, then after looking in two rooms he can't find her so he leaves, then he's marching with the group and he's wearing a bear suit, etc.Because of the choppiness of the editing I could only assume that this was in connection with the pills Cage's character is popping throughout the movie and it's got to turn out to be "this was all a hallucination" stirred on by the trauma the character went through having seen the girl burn up in the car and not being able to save her. I would have been disappointed, but at least it would have made the whole film cohesive.In addition, there were some other scenes that should have been cut because they were just confusing, such as Cage running into a room and seeing Sobieski covered in bees, and the scene when Cage sees a woman in the field and says, "Aren't you Sister Rose? Didn't I just speak with you?" and she says no. I didn't even think it was the same actress. And if it was, what the hell did that mean? This movie needed to be kept much more simple and systematic. Then, step by step we would have seen Cage's character, the "fly" if you will, being led and ultimately caught in the spider's web. We would not have understood what was happening until the end, but then at the end we would be able to look back on the whole thing and it would all make sense. The plot is complex enough. It would have shone through, if everything else in the film was kept simple.And if I were to substitute the beginning car inferno scene with something, it would have been some history and perhaps flashbacks of Cage's character with Willow, so that we had something to connect with when he travels all the way there to help her.Sometimes it is fun to see a badly made movie and pick it apart. If you agree, then go see THE WICKER MAN.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2006-09-05</date>
		<username>Julie Hoverson</username>
		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>Not worth it, but not god-awful</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>My friend Pat and I, after watching this film, had to sit in the theatre and figure out exactly what we hated about it. She: Nicholas Cage, everything else; me: the feeling that some significant elements were lost in translation from the original.OK, that wasn't ALL I hated, but I like to be specific.First, I didn't find the movie UNWATCHABLE. Watch it for free, and you will TOTALLY get your money's worth.The first HUGE thing I found annoying was - in the original, a police officer goes to a small insular island community on an anonymous tip that a small girl has gone missing. The town/island of Summerisle, however, is fairly NORMAL (normal for Scotland in the early 1970s, anyway). It has a pub. It has a castle. It doesn't get many visitors, or want many visitors, but it is pretty average, if a little behind the times. In the remake, the island/town is just plain WEIRD. Rather than "behind the times" or "hick-ish" it's practically Amish - well, OK, it looks like something from around 1900-1917 - and women are in charge, and men don't talk.The problem I had is this: "creepy things happening in a normal setting is MUCH MORE creepy". Once you're in a weird town, finding weird things seems normal. In a "regular" town, finding weird things is eerie. You wouldn't expect a drag queen in full showgirl regalia on the streets of Des Moines Iowa (apologies to any Iowan drag queens if I am wrong), but wouldn't look twice at one in Las Vegas.The second thing was belief. In the original, the Laird of Summerisle basically admitted (whether truthfully or not) to the cop that he himself didn't actually believe any of the old religion, it was just a way to keep his people happy. Which makes it MUCH MORE creepy that the Laird would condone, and in fact take part in, the final ritual. You may not agree with true believers, but at least you can figure they are passionate about what they do - an opportunist, however, that's creepy.OK, and the whole bee thing was weird - plus they didn't get it right. Males shouldn't have been working at all, since the only "bee males" are drones and don't do any work. Sigh.OH, and I think in the future I will stay away from any movie set in the San Juan islands which involves a church or church ruin. Apparently Summersisle is just across the channel from the Isla De Muerte (from House of the Dead). ...shuddder...</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>The 1973 film for me while slightly missing out on the classic status was very effective and well done, very bizarre and disturbing when it needed to be and elevated by a brilliant Christopher Lee especially. Anyway that is enough, for I am not going to try comparing the film to this dross. Both this and the Psycho remakes were completely unnecessary and awful on their own terms, but if I had to edge out which was worse, Psycho but that is not saying much.This remake of The Wicker Man may be glossy, it may be expensive, but guess what? In my opinion, it was completely and utterly pointless as well. It was hilarious but for all the wrong reasons, whether it is the meaningless plot change about Nicolas Cage's character being allergic to bees or the finale, which was way overdone in the sense I couldn't stop laughing.The film certainly looks glossy and expensive, but that's the thing, they overdo it with the visuals as well so it all looks flashy with no sense of melancholy or menace underneath. And I can't count the number of scenes that were dumbed or dulled down, even the pagan May Day rituals weren't that convincing, not to mention the plot, dull, thin and meandering. The script is sorely lacking as well the dialogue at worst was absolutely laughable, as is the direction, and I was not impressed by the acting either. Nicolas Cage is an uninspired lead literally sleepwalking through his role, while Kate Beahan and Ellen Burstyn(who was so brilliant in Requiem for a Dream) can't do anything with their characters, no surprise seeing as the script leaves them little to work with.Overall, a real mess of a remake with next to no redeeming qualities. The bottom line is give it a pass and watch the far superior original instead. 1/10 Bethany Cox</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Best comedy I've seen this year</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>How did THIS masterpiece go overlooked? Such a great movie. It's one of those movie for movie buffs really, but I'm sure even the broader mainstream audience will pick on its genius. That's what this is: sheer genius.It might be unintentionally so, but how many times do you see a --Bear Suit-- in the final act of a film being pulled out with such nonchalant bravery? The beginning might leave you a little confused, but the moment you catch that horrible acting delivered by the police buddy you get a hint of what's to come: a lot of laugh-out-loud moments. Many lines of dialog are sure to become cult classic, such as "Phallic symbols, phallic symbols", "The bees are in my eyes", "How'd it get burned? X 4", "Step away from the bike" and many others.It could use a little trimming in the editing, but the slow moments are crucial to enhance the precision with which it walks on the fine line that separates farce from tragedy. Highly recommended to any film fan or to anybody looking for some (many) laughs.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>It's not a comedy; despite how funny Cage seemed in the bear suit, burning up, screaming repeatedly?Oh Boy! It's not a thriller; otherwise it's the longest, most incomprehensible, one. And it's not a horror, since I've been searching all the time for something horrific, else that script, to not find any. It's simply?a "bad" movie. And frankly, as a bad movie it is so watchable since its badness hit a unique level ! It looked like a never-ending and so stupid X File. True that there are many many thrilling moments, but the abundance of them, without any mind to control the plot or clear it up, made the whole thing as perfectly implausible and weary. Don't dare to ask what was the fact behind the blind twin sisters?, the silence of the men?, the meaning of the dead people that the lead finds in the palace?, what was in the bloody bag?, why the teacher locked up the crow?, or the reason why they didn't kill the lead since the start; as long as the whole thing is about killing him anyway ??!! (Well, that was for selling the air to us !). The wise advice here is: don't even think, as this movie didn't in the first place ! Matters like remembering the first scene in different dreams, or recalling certain memories in variable ways were all parts of the movie's plan to fill not to fulfill. The script feels as meat without bones. Just actions without one action or one step ahead. Instead of leading a live mysterious horror, it kept padding pointless images one after another till it killed the thrill, transforming the movie into a swollen stuffed animal. That's why the way of making it; is more appalling than whatever it presents, since you wonder; what kind of movie that has no drama, one solid storyline, ascending.. etc ?! The no effort to make a story, the absurdness of everything, and underrating the viewer's mentality to this extent represent a real horror for me ! Thus, with none other than empty circles round and round foolishly on screen, the eventual outcome was absolute drivel. Actually discovering that, at the end, was highly painful. At that point I was amazed, not out of the movie's hoax, but out of the movie's fact as hoax ! So why they remade it ?? Again, it's to fill. Fill the cinemas out there. The studio needed a movie, so why not to follow the very easy style lately; make new one by remaking already present another. The thing is that prevailing style, rather epidemic, has its famous symptom; THE IDIOT SCRIPT. And if the writer were that smart from the start, then they would have fulfilled whether good remakes or original movies (The most missed 2 things in Hollywood of today!).I think no re-editing could fix it to be meaningful or at least no monster. Its producers themselves, after watching it, got no guts to screen it for critics. And we read that Edward Woodward, star of the original movie, has said that while he was offered a part in the remake and declined, he nevertheless was "surprisingly impressed by the quality of the script" ??!! So, he's maybe courteous, hypocrite, or has a shitty taste !What's good then ? I loved only one moment in which Nick punches the fat woman in her face. I needed this punch to unchain my negative emotions towards the silliness of this woman and this movie. Moreover, after seeing Connery in a bear suit during the infamous (The Avengers), then Nick in the same suit during this one, I learned that wearing a bear suit in any movie must be a sign for being awful! And finally, you've got to respect the principles of the movie's makers; they believed in their work (faith), got the nerve to release it (boldness), and made something rarely bad (the desire of superiority) ! As long as the wicker man is someone who goes through worldly inferno, being tricked by evil people who burn him in fire for no crime he committed, then I'm, as the viewer of this movie, The True Wicker Man, with every poor one watched it too !</fullReview>

So Edward travels to the private island of Summerisle, where Willow lives which is in an odd community that happen to plant fruits, she reveals that Rowan is their daughter. 		<username>David Gray</username>
		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>It begs the question: why?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Everything that I thought after watching this film centred around the word 'why':Why was this film necessary? Why have they made pointless, irrelevant changes to the original? Why is Nicholas Cage still cast in anything? Why have I just paid ?4.50 to see this futile rubbish?I just can't comprehend why Neil LaBute felt he needed to change every single thing about the original that made it a classic. Unlike a lot of people, I actually saw the original after I saw this remake, and I was baffled as to what the point in the new one is.Once in a blue moon, there is a good remake of an old film. Peter Jackson's 'King Kong' is an example of this - it didn't undermine the original at all and yet was still a superbly made film. But LeBute is no Peter Jackson, and there was nothing in this film to bring it to life. Cage was simply dull and the way his voice tails off towards the end of the sentence is one of those little things that will probably annoy you throughout the entirety of this film. I can't think of what the demographic was for this film. Perhaps unsighted fools like me. Fans of the original will hate it for how unfaithful it is to Anthony Shaffer's original screenplay. People who haven't seen the original will dislike it for the fact that it is... well... boring. There is no explanation as to how they get from one scene to another which makes it feel far too long, and there is no tension at all - you know that whenever anyone opens a box a bat will fly out.***SPOILERS START HERE***The ending is probably the worst part of the film (quite an achievement). The sight of the Wickerman burning the Cage to death (although it may make you cheer given that you are made to intensely dislike his character. Either that or you will just dislike him) could be made poignant and shocking - it certainly was when Seargant Howie was burnt in the original. So why did you need to see what happened 6 months later? It was completely unnecessary.In the words of Alan Hansen, it was diabolical.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>A bizarre island hard to reach and even harder to leave.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>California cop Edward Malus(Nicolas Cage)takes some time off after a woman and her small daughter die in a fiery crash. It happened so fast all he could do is watch and his rescue attempts failed. Still recovering from this traumatic tragedy, Malus receives a call from his former girlfriend Willow(Kate Beahan), who asks him to come to a private island off of Washington state to help find her daughter Rowan(Erika-Shaye Gair). Malus arrives on Summersisle and finds the occupants are a bit bizarre. The community is under the iron fist rule of Sister Summersisle(Ellen Burstyn). The island is populated by women who treat men as second-class citizens and take part in ancient rituals and human sacrifice. Malus has no idea what he is getting into as he desperately hunts for the lost little girl.This film seems too contrived and the acting is pretty damn stale. There is absolutely no chemistry between Cage and his leading lady Beahan. Burstyn is eerie as the clan's matriarch. Other cast members: Leelee Sobieski, Frances Conroy, Diane Delano and Molly Parker.</fullReview>

I believe in the movie as like the original the bees and honey failed so thats why they had to sacrifice Malus to bring the bees and honey back to life, and burning him in the Wicker Man would solve their problems as it would please the Gods, however at the end Willow and a friend are picking up new victims obviously for their next sacrifice, which in a way discounts the whole notion of the movie on Pagan rituals, that a sacrifice will make the crops thrive, so I found that utterly stupid.When comparing this to the original, the actors in this were terrible especially Burnstyn, Cage and the one who played Willow as she seemed very indecisive about everything. The music was unoriginal compared to the original, nothing was explained very well in the remake, like their way of life, and the ideas of the animal costumes and going deep into their religion and its beliefs. I also didn't like the slight hints at rip off from other films ie don't look now (the girl in the red dress leading the man to his death) and village of the dammed (most of the kids in bland clothes and with blonde hair).Overall I was disappointed I think if I hadn't seen the original I might have given it 5 out of 10, but as their were little shocks and little interest for all involved, only watch if you have time to kill.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2006-11-18</date>
		<username>lanzig138</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>The Very Foundation That 'Mystery Science Theater 3000' Was Built On!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Film Review: The Wicker Man (2006) Directed By: Neil LaBute Starring: Nicolas Cage, Ellen Burstyn, Leelee Sobieski, Molly Parker and some chick with grotesquley big lips.WARNING: THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS....but does it really matter? Question: Are you the type of person who could enjoy a movie in which Nicolas Cage karate kicks a bunch of annoying feminists? I AM!!! I really enjoyed this film. Not because it was good mind you, but because it was so entertainly bad. This is the real deal, the very foundation that 'Mystery Science Theater 3000' was built on! One thing elevates this film from being an unwatchable piece of s**t to pure comedic gold and that one thing is Sir Nicolas Cage.Let's talk about Cage for a moment. What can I say? The man is an enigma. Is he more than a little strange? Yes. Am I disturbed by the fact that he named his son Kal-el? Yes. Do I still find myself oddly attracted to him? YES. I think he's a brilliant actor who's capable of handling dark dramatic roles (8MM), eccentric comedic roles (Raising Arizona) and weird Christopher Walkeney type roles (Vampire's Kiss). He is now heading into Charlton Heston territory.The plot of the The New 'Wicker Man' is as follows: A police officer (Cage) witnesses a freak car accident (really freak because it makes no goddamn sense and is never explained). It tramatizes him (I guess?) so he just lays around on his couch popping pills. One day he receives a letter (no stamp on it so don't ask me how it got there) from his ex fiancée (played by the fish lip lady) begging him to come help her find her daughter who has been missing for two weeks. She lives on a remote island that has no phone service so the information he gets in the letter is all he has to go on. Now his ex dumped him in a pretty harsh manner so why he chooses to go help that bitch is beyond me. Though one of his co-workers is of sound mind and tells him to not go...guess what? Cage then ends up on this "Fantasy Island" which is inhabited by a cult of hairy arm pitted, birkenstock sandal wearing, Indigo Girl listening, Lilith Fair rejects. Mere moments after his arrival he becomes instantly annoyed with these people. Wouldn't you? He meets up with the ex and she tells him that no one on the island believes that her daughter actually exists. Apparently, the cult is run by an "earth mother" type known as Sister Summersisle (played by Burstyn) who doesn't take too kindly to fish woman's "wild ways" (being as how fish woman once ran away from the place and became involved with Cage). Therefore fish lady thinks that Burstyn is hiding the kid. But as Cage starts to ask around he gets a variety of stories. He's told everything from "she's not really Fish Lady's kid" to "Fish Lady's kid did exist but she burned to death in an accident" and back to "Fish Lady's kid never existed in the first place". Okay, then Cage goes back to fish lady to vent his frustration over his failure to come up with any evidence. She then tells Cage that the girl is his daughter. Didn't see that one coming! (Please note the sarcasm.) We are then subjected to more cryptic scenes such as Cage being attacked by bees, a few dream within a dream pop out sequences, and a "what's behind that door?" chase sequence through Burstyn's house in which Cage stumbles upon a naked man covered in moles. At one point during the film, Cage looks at the Fish Lady and says "I'm completely lost.". I can't begin to tell you how f**king funny that line was to me. This movie does not make one lick of sense and it has plot holes wider than Jessica Simpson's "ravaged by the cast of Jackass" vagina. But like I wrote earlier, there is some comedy gold here. Cages sarcasm towards the islanders is hilarious! You just want him to punch one of these broads in the face and sure enough...HE DOES!!!! He also has a complete throw down with Leelee Sobieski (who's looking really hot in this flick!). As for the big sacrifice scene, be prepared to bust a gut! This is the only part of the movie that sticks to the original except here it's not scary. Prior to hoisting Cage up into the Wicker Man (where he will suffer his firey fate) the islanders break Cage's legs prompting him to yell out "MY LEGS!!! MY LEGS!!!! YOU BITCHES!!!!!".But wait until the "six months later scene" which takes place in a bar. The last five seconds are the funniest I've HEARD all year! Will you like this sort of thing? That I don't know. I want to recommend it to those who love "good bad" movies. I'm not sure that you would want to spend the full ten dollars on it so maybe just do a matinée. But if you miss the matinée, please be sure to rent it when it hits DVD. It truly has to be seen to be believed.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Typical Neil LaBute.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>He has a problem with women, they are always portrayed as cold and evil in his work, so an island full of them isn't a stretch. Even the little girl in the beginning is cruel. That's the big problem in this film. Labute doesn't like women, therefore the women in this movie are not likable, therefore it's not as interesting or thought provoking as the original. Nicolas Cage doesn't help matters, his character seems less stoic than and more comatose. Who are you supposed to relate to when both sides are unlikable? And the movie is strangely square. The British version from 1973 is far more dangerous, even if it's soundtrack is filled with folk music, especially because it's soundtrack is filled with folk music. This Wicker Man is PG-13! Since the women are demonic, they wouldn't be shown in a sexual way, the only reason the original is R-rated. So you're left with a tame, lame version of good story beaten down by it's adaptor's prejudices.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2007-08-03</date>
		<username>petra_ste</username>
		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>Sorry, you're gonna have to BEAR with me</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>If you want a GOOD horror/thriller, this most certainly isn't one. However, if you appreciate a so-bad-it's-funny movie, this is a fantastic choice - I was laughing so hard I nearly died. I enjoy Nicholas Cage in quirky roles (Adaptation, Matchstick Men) but his work here is the kind of performance old actors remember with horror as the most embarrassing moments of their lives. His Edward Malus behaves like a mix between a psycho and a moron (emphasis on "moron"); it looks as if Cage was trying to channel Homer J. Simpson (now that I think about it, this would be perfect as a Simpsons Halloween Special). His whole performance has a delightfully ludicrous quality to it - the way he alternates between shouting and mumbling in a sleepy monotone, his reaction shots to every situation, from trivial sights to absurd occurrences. He even runs funny.To be fair, Cage is given such horrible lines and uproarious scenes - running around in a bear suit, rolling down a hill pursued by bees - it's not entirely his fault. In fact, all other performers - from lovely Molly Parker, Leelee Sobieski and Kate Beahan (who deserves an award for the best "deer caught in the headlights" impression) to award-winning Ellen Burstyn - are also terrible, although not funny as Cage. What's amazing is NO ONE of the dozens of professionals involved in the making of this movie realized they were doing an unintentional comedy - and yeah, it was unintentional; don't believe anyone who claims otherwise, because the film speaks for itself here. How could director LaBute think someone was going to take his remake of The Wicker Man seriously, it's flat-out astonishing. Maybe he was too busy cramming in as many Freudian/sexual references as possible, expecting a lot of "ooooh! clever!" reactions.This will become a cult classic, something Ed Wood would have been proud of. 3/10 as a serious movie, but as a comedy it's a 10/10.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Oh the horror! Oh the mystery!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I used to have this goldfish named Flushy. He basically swam around his bowl, ate a bit, pooped a bit, and occasionally ate a bit of his poop. I generally do not consider those who dine upon their own excrement to be of the highest intellectual caliber. I grossly underestimated poor Flushy's commercial value, however. 		<date>2007-01-18</date>
		<username>CelluloidRehab (lelnu@yahoo.com)</username>
		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>Worthy of most things Shatnerian - "Why is .. it .. BURNED ??.... Why ...isitburned???</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It is unfortunate that I review this movie after just seeing Crank. I still think I am seeing spots and I am definitely coming down. Solipsist and Oscar winning master thespian, Nicholas Cage, stars in either a farcical story of cross-cultural misunderstanding or in a unintended B-movie-like-comedy, complete with over-the-top, Shatner-like acting. I think it is the latter, but I leave it up to history and the experts to decide. So the Cage, as I like to call him, is doing his best impersonation of Erik Estrada in Chips. He gets a note from his fiancée, which states that her daughter is missing and if he could help. Mind you, this is the woman who disappeared from his life, years before. She lives on an isolated island in the Northwest part of the country. An island that is mostly populated by a female Amish/Quaker-like commune. The rest is relatively meaningless. If you want meaning, you might as well check out the original movie. This movie is just there for the laughs.The Cage is not a very good actor. As one of my comrades one said of him - "He's the same in every movie." He is an actor playing himself and not doing it very well. The Cage has been in some good movies, however, those were built around his "particular idiom" (Lord of War is a great example of this). On the other end, when you try to get him to act or make him feel emotion, you get this Botox coma or perhaps City of Angels. His performance in this movie can simple described as mind-numbingly-nuked. He is part angry octogenarian, part whiny, part drunk, all high-school production quality with 1/2 a bottle of pain killers. I mean the scenes in the bear suit are priceless, not to mention all the cheap shots he dishes out. Unfortunately, the hilarity mostly ensues well past the 60 minute mark. Prior to this, feel free to snicker and laugh at the lame, lame dialog. I can definitely say skip the theatrical version (go straight for the unrated version) of this movie, as you will be getting a slow motion montage-like procession scene with sound overlay instead of the actual scene. I actually was scratching my head, wondering, the first time I saw/heard it. Oh well. Highly recommended for a laugh. If you want to skip the movie all together, check out Youtube for a compilation of the best and funniest scenes in the movie. I think it's a fair trade - 3 minutes in the Cage or 90. ........................Wise choice.</fullReview>

		<username>Corky1984</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A decent remake</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Before I start, I'd best say that in my view the original Wicker Man was a better film, but not by much. This new remake sees the story faithfully retold with a few changes for a modern audience. Usually I'm the first to criticise remakes, especially when they tone down the violence or 'edge' of the original, but in this case, I reckon they did a pretty decent job. Nicholas Cage is a good actor who brought plenty to the role played by Edward Woodward in the first version. I'd say Cage was actually better in fact. The key ingredient missing from this new interpretation, however, was Christopher Lee. I felt that he made the 1970s version and his replacement in this wasn't anywhere near as sinister, but aside from that, the remake is good. This time, its set in a remote island somewhere in the USA, rather than Scotland. Visually, the new film is far more satisfying as a result. The soundtrack is nothing special, but compared to Woodward's picture, its a vast improvement. This wasn't as gritty a film as its predecessor, but nevertheless, I felt it didn't change too many things from the plot. The acting was on the whole good. What was missing was the original's scenes of nudity etc, but for a 12A I never expected them to reappear. I find it strange that I enjoyed this to be honest, but I did! Cage is at his best when playing a slightly odd character, with traits of nerviness. Here he shined. I know this film gets poor reviews from many, but give it a go if you have an open mind.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2006-09-08</date>
		<username>digitig-1</username>
		<score>0.2</score>
		<shortDescription>Whereas the original transcended multiple genres, this version flunks them.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It can perhaps be unfair to compare a remake with an original when one loves the original: every change will seem a flaw, even when to somebody new to the film the changed might seem an improvement. But in this case, I think that reference to the original genuinely helps to pinpoint what's wrong with the remake.Part of the genius of the original was the the slow but relentless build-up, the way one was never quite sure where one's sympathies should lie, the way one is never sure what's going on. Slow build ups don't seem to be the fashion now, and so we get crashes and fireballs from the start. And it's made clear from the very outset that the cop (Cage) is the good guy, and nothing changes this view throughout (even when he slugs women, it's with good cause). And the inhabitants of Summersisle don't even try to hide the fact that they practice human sacrifice. So: no subtlety, then.Losing the subtlety is bad enough, but what about the story? Well, in the original the individual, seemingly unrelated, adversities that the cop suffers all turn out to be cleverly building together to meet a complex set of criteria for the climax. Well, that had the word "complex" in it, so it plainly wasn't going to happen in this version. Instead, most of those adversities (some of them from the original) turn out to be completely irrelevant to the plot, the criteria for the climax this time being very simple. Which left me wondering, "Why did they do that, then?". The plot becomes a string of beads from which the string has been removed, leaving the beads -- the individual scenes -- rolling around uselessly.Themes? The original had a conflict between Christianity and Pagainism (even if it got a bit confused between Roman Catholic and Presbyterian forms of Christianity). Well, far be it from Hollywood to give Christianity any credence now; it's only glimpsed in this version as something plainly dead and out of the equation. "Self-help" books and pharmaceuticals look as if they might fill its place, but ultimately the film turns into a nauseatingly misogynous men v. women conflict, with paganism not set against anything in particular. And whereas the original was relentlessly natural, the clumsy topping-and-tailing of the story try to give this version unnecessary supernatural overtones (and an excuse for some clumsy hallucinations in the vain hope of making it a "proper" horror film).With better acting from the scenery than the cast (was Leelee Sobieski just cast for her ability to roll her eyes badly?) and a horror-by-numbers musical score, there really is no reason to see this film. Whereas the original transcended multiple genres (horror, thriller, musical, drama...), this version flunks them all.I suppose some of the scenery and photography is OK.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>

	<review>
		<date>2006-09-05</date>
		<username>HalRagland</username>
		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>LaBute, Cage And Company Have Committed Murder, And The Victim Is A Great Film Called "The Wicker Man"</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I saw a murder committed this Labor Day at a movie theater near me, and the victim's name is a great film called "Anthony Schaffer's The Wicker Man". Neil LaBute's dreadful remake of "Anthony Schaffer's The Wicker Man" might very well be the most unnecessary remake since Gus Van Sant's shot-by-shot remake of "Psycho". This movie should never have been made.This an utterly dreadful contemporary Hollywood defiling of a British classic. The remake follows the basic plot of the original. A cop, named Edward Malus, a.k.a. Sgt. Howie in the original, played by an overacting Nicolas Cage, is lured to an island called "Summersisle" by a letter reporting a missing girl, this time on Puget Sound in Western Washington state instead of Scotland. Like in the original, Malus discovers an unhelpful neo-pagan community who appear to be ready to sacrifice the girl he is looking for after a disastrous crop failure the previous year.Along the way the makers of the remake have made some "creative" changes to the original. Gone is the clash of religious beliefs, replaced with a battle of the sexes. The island in the remake is a matriarchy filled with unlikable, man-hating females, and subservient mute males, and led by a matriarch named "Sister Summersisle" (Ellen Burstyn).Gone is the compelling character of the devoutly Christian cop Sgt. Howie from the original. Gone is the ideal sacrifice who is a virgin, a man who represents the law and is King for Day, replaced with an aimless, secular, pill popping dolt of a cop from California named Ed Malus, played by an overacting Nicolas Cage, who, in an extraordinary departure from the original plot, turns out to be the father of the girl he is trying to rescue.In the original the Punch costume worn by Howie symbolizes the Fool and the King for a Day, or part of what makes Howie an ideal sacrifice for the islanders. In the remake comedy ensues as Ed Malus dons a silly bear suit. The islanders never tell Malus the meaning of his suit or what it has to do with his impending sacrifice. Hence, the silly bear suit symbolizes all the attributes of a movie that seems to be trying to get multiple Razzie nominations (Cage and his bear suit received a nomination for "Worst On screen Couple").The sacrifice of Sgt. Howie at the end of the original is a chilling homage to Christian martyrs of the past, and the viewer doesn't doubt for a second that he is a martyr who is sacrificed in part for his religious beliefs. In the remake you can only laugh when Malus is told that he is dying a martyr's death. Martyr for what? Popping pills all day and his self-help book? Yes, the ineptness of the execution of the film is so bad it makes you laugh, but this is hardly a credit to the makers of the film. The film is not categorized as a comedy and yet viewers are counting the ways it made them laugh. The funniest line of them all is when Malus yells, "Killing me won't bring back your goddamn honey!" More comedy ensues as Cage knocks out three female cast members. Some are arguing that it should be a comedy, and they've got a point. It just doesn't raise my opinion of the film.Watching the actors in the film deliver their lines you get the sense that nobody in this movie is taking it seriously, and are only doing it for a paycheck. Perhaps this is because everybody in the cast recognized that they were making a turkey that would be ridiculed as one of the worst films of the year.May this dreck garner many a Golden Raspberry nomination (It got five) this Spring. May it also be sacrificed to the Gods and Goddesses of Great Film-making this May Day, so that we might have a better crop of Summer movies to see next year. Overall, a dreary moment in film history I regret having seen.</fullReview>
	</review>
