	<review>
		<date>2014-03-14</date>
		<username>Wuchak</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Destined for cult status</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Negative reviewers make Neil LaBute's 2006 remake of "The Wicker Man" out to be an incredulous turkey on the level of "Plan 9 from Outer Space" and "American Beauty," but it's simply not the case.First of all, let's be honest about the original 1973 version: Yes, it's a unique and original film in multiple ways and has numerous strengths, including fine Scottish locations and the presence of Britt Ekland and Ingrid Pitt (the former's siren-like "How Do" song &amp; dance is a definite highlight), but it's not the masterpiece that many claim. What's wrong with it? For one thing, the protagonist, Sgt. Howie (Edward Woodward), is annoying and unlikable; he comes off as a Pharasaical tighty-righty (which is how he struck me and I'm a Christian!). This is a serious flaw when you consider that the entire film focuses on Woodward's progressive search for the missing girl. In addition, Christopher Lee is just 'there' as Lord Summerisle (which is blasphemy to Lee fans since Lee considered his part in "Wicker Man" his personal best). The biggest problem with the original is that the film plays out in a dull manner; the plot itself is interesting, but the delivery isn't.Woodward is so unlikable and annoying that, on some subconscious level, I was almost glad with his outcome at the end. Which brings up another criticism of the original film: I didn't find the ending horrifying. It was supposed to be, but somehow it wasn't.One last criticism of the 1973 original is that it's understandably dated. It's obvious a product of the free-love hippie era and it shows. If any film screamed out for a remake this was it. THE PLOT: The story in this new version switches to America. Nicholas Cage plays a California cop searching for his ex-fiancé's daughter on a mysterious privately owned island in Washington's Puget Sound. The society is backwards, pagan and matriarchal; the men are mute and second class. As the film progresses, Cage comes to see that the inhabitants are lying to him about the girl's disappearance.WHAT WORKS: Unlike Woodward, Cage is likable as the protagonist (or, at least, we can relate to him). His mounting frustration and anger over the situation are understandable. When he ultimately turns to outright violence against the women we understand what has driven him to such actions.The British Columbian locations are good, pretty much on a par with the Scottish locations of the original in their own unique way.Ellen Burstyn is better than Christopher Lee as the villain. We don't even meet her until an hour into the film and she comes off as a creepy religious psycho (just because she's pagan doesn't mean she's not religious). Lee was bland in the original.Molly Parker as the school teacher and Leelee Sobieski are fetching (with Kate Beahan a distant third). Molly and Leelee are fully clothed at all times and yet somehow ooze beauty. Molly, in particular, has a very unique allure. One reviewer complained that there weren't any scenes of naked women as was frequently the case in the original, but the director didn't feel the need to go the softcore porn route. Lebute shows that true beauty is far more than numerous displays of softcore eroticism and overt nudity. If you want that rent a porn video.The story is generally entertaining, sometimes fun and, at times, unintentionally amusing. For instance, the scene where Cage talks with the "barmaid" and the patrons has some laugh-out-loud aspects. There are other humorous moments (Cage apprehending the bicycle: "STEP AWAY FROM THE BIKE!", running around in a bear costume, the dead girl suddenly appearing in his arms on the dock, numerous hilarious lines like "OH NO, NOT THE BEES, NOT THE BEES!!", etc.). Despite this, the picture somehow maintains a serious aura. The original, by contrast, was dead-pan serious and never entertained in this manner.The ending is horrifying (more so than the original), even though I knew it was coming. If you're in the right mood it can also be funny. The alternate ending is even better with the inclusion of overt torture scenes (although I know why they cut one of the torture scenes, the bees would've killed Cage since he was allergic to them). The Wicker Man prop is intimidating and over twice the size of the original.In the theatrical version there's a "6 months later" coda tacked on, which is an important scene. It shows how pre-meditated the actions of the women are in the film. It also explains one of Leelee's mysterious lines earlier in the story, "When you leave, take me with you." This sequence shouldn't have been cut from the alternate ending.WHAT DOESN'T WORK: The search-in-the-barn sequence is pretty useless, but adds to the mounting mystery. Also, the story really bogs down in the graveyard scene where Cage and Kate have a heart-to-heart talk.Some people may look down on the film because of the unintentionally funny scenes noted above. I think it makes it more entertaining. If you don't agree with me STEP AWAY FROM THIS REVIEW!FINAL ANALYSIS: Both the 1973 and 2006 versions of "The Wicker Man" are equally valuable for their positive aspects noted above. The insane criticisms of the remake are unwarranted (remakes are, of course, a lose-lose situation: if the film in question is remade frame for frame like "Psycho" people complain, and if the filmmakers deviate from the original they'll complain even more; you can't win). The fact is that the 1973 version is severely dated and NEEDED to be remade, and this is a quality updating. It's worth catching if you like mounting mystery stories with creepy elements. On top of this, there are amusing elements. And, thankfully, the protagonist isn't some irritating legalist with a corncob stuck up his arse.The film runs 102 minutes.GRADE: B</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>Before I start this review, I would like to say that I have not seen the original Wicker Man.This is unexpectedly hilarious even for a film starring Nicholas Cage playing a detective going to an island populated entirely by woman who use men as slaves trying to solve the disappearance of a little girl that's suppose to be his step-daughter. I was confused and bored multiple times throughout the film.But the ending really annoyed me. 		<username>Rickting</username>
		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>Let it burn</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The Wicker Man is the best British horror film of all time, so why did they remake it? What could be gained? Those are just some of the many questions one will ask after watching this unintentional comedy, and they are all virtually unanswerable. The existence of this film is offensive. However, this is not just any horror remake. This is the worst horror remake of all time. There is not one redeeming quality, not one bright spot, not one silver lining. Nicolas Cage, as many have forgotten, is a good actor and apparently Neil LaBute was considered a good director before this misfire. The biggest question of all is how did these 2 talented people and all of the other unfortunate people working on this (Who would probably gladly pay to erase their name from the credits) not realize that this mixture of screaming, bees, bear suits, bicycles, idiots, martial arts, ugliness, plot holes and scares which consist of... nothing is less scary than your average episode of Barney The Dinosaur? Nicolas Cage gives the worst performance by a good actor ever and spends the entire film either being wooden or screaming louder than Jamie Lee Curtis in Halloween, while the other actors are blocks of wood with no personality. The script is toilet paper, with numerous plot holes and a total lack of what made the original so powerful. Neil LaBute may have done some noteworthy things before this, but judging from the direction here this could easily be mistaken for some laughably bad home horror movie made by 10 year olds. Still, at least 10 year olds could make a better horror film than this! This is a movie with no positives at all, and is an offensively pointless, jaw droppingly dreadful movie which has no right to exist expect as a guide for how not to do a horror movie, a Nicolas Cage screaming compilation or an advert for bee keeping and bear suits. There is nothing scary about this film except for the terrifyingly low quality. As for the unintentional comedy... I don't see what's funny about a great film being destroyed. The worst horror film of all time. Objective, not subjective.0/10</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>I have watched the original a few times and think although it is good it is an overrated film. The air of menace so prevalent in the original is mainly lacking here though this could be in part because I knew what was coming. The ending is left the same but it really is not as affecting second time round.As it is, although it is nowhere near as bad as the rating suggests, this is no more than an average remake. It may be worth watching if your not familiar with the first one but if you are it's unlikely you'll find much to satisfy you.</fullReview>

		<date>2012-03-15</date>
		<username>Tyrssen-282-277645</username>
		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>A Hideous Piece of Trash</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Unfortunately, there is no category lower than 1, or I would have given it. This "remake" bears absolutely no resemblance to the original 1973 version. The original was a thriller with pagan overtones, clearly written by people who had done their homework. They did not seek to present a genuine modern pagan viewpoint, but they worked hard to capture the essential flavor, even including a bit of dry humor, right at the beginning. The credits that read, "We would like to thank the people of Summerisle for a look into their religious practices," that sort of thing.This sorry bit of bilge does nothing of the sort. It is simply an exercise in anti-male misogynism. Phony feminism carried to its ultimate level of ridiculousness. Not a single male "resident" ever utters a line, which no doubt saved the producers a fortune but did nothing to establish this film's credibility, which it sorely needed. As a movie which has nothing to do with The Wicker Man, it's a loser, in its own right. The original is a brilliant classic; this one's a lame poser, that has none of the original's insight or TLC. Puke-O-Rama, kids.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2012-01-08</date>
		<username>BA_Harrison</username>
		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>A waste of wicker?they could have made some nice chairs or baskets instead.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>After the absolute mess that was the remake of The Wicker Man, I can only imagine that some sort of human sacrifice was made to appease the horror gods, thus preventing the genre from drying up altogether. Obviously, Nic Cage and Neil LaBute were too well known to go missing, so I have to presume that it was some minor studio exec or unknown extra that went up in flames to atone for this complete abomination.The original film was a masterpiece of suspense, brooding atmosphere, and absolute horror; viewers of director Neil LaBute's version are most likely to experience mounting rage or a fit of uncontrollable laughter, but never a sense of dread or unease. The performances are uniformly awful, the dialogue atrocious (and eminently quote-worthy as a result) and LaBute's sacrilegious screenplay alters far too many key plot elements: the action is moved from Scotland, where the story makes sense, to a small island community in the Puget Sound; the lead character is now an L.A. motorcycle cop; Lord Summerisle becomes Sister Summerisle; and Rowan, the missing girl, is the protagonist's daughter. Worst of all, LeeLee Sobieski doesn't even do a naked dance, which I would have reckoned was a no-brainer.Part of me is tempted to give The Wicker Man a high rating, just because I found it so bloody funny, but I fear that if I did, I could be next in line as a sacrifice from those who didn't find it such a laughing matter. Just to be safe, I give this one a rating of 3/10.</fullReview>

If ya gonna re-make something, then you're supposed to at least make it as good, if not, then better than the original. He failed on both counts. What was he thinking, and what were the producers thinking when they green-lit this stupidity? I don't think Labute himself understood what he was making. At least what he should've done, if he wanted to give it a slightly more glitzy, modern-day look to the film, was to remake the film shot-for- shot as Gus Van Sant did for Psycho. That might have worked, albeit with American accents, of course, and new music. Every scene in this film that was supposed to be somewhat shocking and surprising and scary were executed poorly. Labute seemed to not quite understand where to put the camera, how to cut the jumpy bits, and it just felt as though every scene seemed like a real trifle to direct, as if he was at conflict with the script that he wrote himself! Perhaps Labute was lost for words as to how to describe what he saw when he wrote the new version and that was what made it to the screen, the whole mise-en-scene and photography completely dull and flat, with no real mysterious feeling in any of it. The music also did not help, and that is because the composer must have found it difficult to accompany anything with any sort of crescendo when the shots and scenes sort of go from one to the next in a meander without specific moments of tension that should've heightened everything. It's amazing that these things get made at all, what a waste of time and money for everybody involved (except for the crew and actors who got paid to work on it).</fullReview>

Naturally, Cage goes to the private island she lives on to help out. The island is run by Ellen Burstyn, who heads a female cult of people who wear bird masks and act like the children of the corn.Cage is in really poor form in this picture. Shuffling about clumsily and constantly jumping into water (and emerging dry). It is not meant to be funny, but when you have a procession led by Burstyn with her face painted like a football fan, scores of women in bird masks following her, and Cage disguised in a bear suit, well, you just have to wonder what these people were thinking, and its funny! I was astonished that the players could all keep a straight face (maybe they just did LOTS of takes).And then it ends, with nothing resolved or accomplished. So, aside from its poor script, bad plot, lousy acting, overcast cinematography, lack of suspense, poor score, painfully slow pacing, and overall unintended hilarity, it is a fine film, deserving a -10 stars, if that were possible. 		<username>vram22</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Unusual Story ...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This movie was fairly different than the run-of-the-mill films you normally see. Although it lagged a bit in suspense, I appreciated seeing something fresh. Its beginning, middle and end aren't what you typically get in most modern movies.In very general terms, this movie is about a police officer (Cage) who investigates a missing child report. The interesting thing is that this all takes place in a society of women that is cut-off from the rest of society.While this scenario seems unlikely in real life, the filmmakers do a pretty good job of getting you to believe it during the movie. The society that the lead character enters is so different that it in itself gets you interested in the movie.Although the movie doesn't elicit the suspense the filmmakers probably desired, it does manage to create a sense of desperation for the lead character. He is cutoff from the world and it is easy to feel his frustration and limited options.If you're a Cage fan, this is not his best performance. It's hard to tell if it is due to him or the way the character is written; either way the lead character is a bit weak.This is worth seeing if you're in the mood for something very different. If you're looking for a really good "standard" thriller, action or suspense movie, this may not be the best choice.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>A truly horrible movie experience</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It's unfortunate that you can't go any lower than one star. Prior to watching The Wicker Man, I had considered Aliens 3 to be the only movie that would actually merit negative stars. In all fairness, The Wicker Man doesn't detract from the enjoyment of an earlier film, but the fact remains that my cumulative movie enjoyment has been reduced by seeing it.There is a cheap trick all too often used in Hollywood when the producers are too stingy to hire good writers or in too much of a hurry to allow them to bring a plot to a satisfactory conclusion: slap in a shocker ending and hope that the public will mistake it for something artistic or meaningful. It is a gambit that rarely succeeds and in this case manages only to splatter embarrassment on a fine actor and ridicule upon the producers. Even more so in that the "carefully crafted" (or however they put it) conclusion didn't seem to follow logically from the plot (which naturally I can't elaborate on without introducing spoilers), and instead negates what merit the plot had up to that point.It is a film that might logically appeal to psychopaths, pedophiles, and possibly die-hard Nicholas Cage fans, but only to a few of the mainstream audience. If you really want something along these lines, I heartily recommend M. Night Shyamalan's The Village instead. Lacking some kind of memory-erasing pill, I suppose I need to watch something better to force it from my mind, say, Attack of the Killer Tomatoes or Pee-wee's Big Adventure?</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2007-07-28</date>
		<username>eirenightshade</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A visual feast</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>While I have not seen the original version, I do not see why there are so many negative comments about this film. True, the story is thin, but it is irresistible. I think people try to read more into it than what is actually there, and therefor miss the delightfully subtle plot altogether. Yes, the acting is bland and lackluster...these people ARE SUPPOSED to be dull and lackluster, they are more or less feminist zombies, meant to appall us with their total lack of human emotion. This is a huge part of the story, NOT bad acting. In fact, if these characters appalled us as much as they did, then I would call them fantastic actors as they pulled it off flawlessly. You're not supposed to like them, people! The story did not fascinate me nearly as much as the imagery, however. The scenes were breathtaking set in a summery location that was meant to be far removed from civilization and succeeded. When watching this film, I was sucked in, completely able to believe the isolated surroundings, adding to the feeling of complete aloneness. The area was beautiful albeit disturbing.This was by no means a life changing movie, but it was a good and solid one. The director chose a path for this film and did not stray from it which is something I cannot say for most directors today who are hellbent on making a film that veers off into twenty directions and leaves more questions than answers. This film was simple and stayed consistent all the way to the finish, though I was left wondering exactly what the young girl with braids and the accident at the beginning had to do with the story. With as many times as they recapped it in Edward's memory I was sure it would go somewhere. No matter, I wasn't disappointed with The Wicker Man. It is always a feat to have only one solid (stable) character in a film and not have it be lifeless. Films with Nicholas Cage are never lifeless as he brings a presence on screen that is believable and likable.Overall, it was a good, solid film. Nothing that knocked my socks off, but it left some gorgeous imagery in my head and as a writer, the visuals in this movie were believable enough to leave me feeling inspired. Perhaps the plot could have been a bit thicker, but I applaud it for not succumbing to America's blatant refusal to enjoy any film without non-stop action and things being blown up. This is a cluster of a movie meant to be be enjoyed by intelligent people who can use their imagination a little more than the stereotypical moviegoer.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2007-05-06</date>
		<username>drew30319</username>
		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>Very frustrating</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Although I realized that this movie hadn't received good reviews I decided to watch it today (there's not a great deal of HD-DVD movies out yet and I took a chance on it).It was clear early on that this movie would not be good. While that's certainly not my preference it's unfortunately common and I settled in to watch a bad film. But this film raced past "not good" and quickly became very frustrating. Frustrating because there appeared to be some potential. Potential to make a decent film and that's what is so annoying and disappointing.(1) Nicolas Cage is generally a good actor but needs strong direction. The first 3/4 of this movie was way off the mark for his character and was distracting and irritating.(2) Serving up predigested plot only appeals to the lowest common denominator. Possibly this was LaBute's goal as he did edit to a PG-13 to reach the 10-16 market (not exactly a group known for their discriminating taste in films).(3) Burstyn was acceptable in her first scene but became unfortunately mired in LaBute's re-write and directing in the final scene.(4) The cinematography ranged from beautiful vistas to hackneyed "portending doom" and the same is true of the score. Why oh why are they trying to create the wrong tone and pace? As I've only seen the film on HD-DVD I haven't seen what was apparently the "theatrical release." I'm surprised that it would be acceptable to change the ending without any statement to that effect. I rented the movie online and may have missed the box art emblazoned with "Director's Cut" or something to indicate the difference. Nevertheless I'm surprised that there's no option on the disc to view the "original ending" or anything that would even imply that the ending is different. I only just found out about the difference by reading on this site.Very frustrating film. And again - not simply because it's poorly done but because all of the pieces were in place to make, at a minimum, a decent film.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Watching This Movie Won't Bring Back Your Honey!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Without question, 'The Wicker Man' is one of the best, most hilariously awful movies I have ever seen. The movie draws a lot of unintentional laughs, thanks to the sheer absurdity of a few scenes.The only real shame that comes from 'The Wicker Man' is that there isn't a show like 'Mystery Science Theater 3000' to lampoon this little gem.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2007-03-07</date>
		<username>Dribbleglass</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Unwarranted, unnecessary, unbelievably silly...this one has it all!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Does every movie need to be remade? The answer is a resounding NO. The insipid and tortuously silly recent remake of "The Wicker Man" is a prime example of this. Only the Adam Sandler interpretation of "Mr. Deeds Goes to Town" has offended me more in recent memory. You're going to remake a Gary Cooper movie? WHY? Anyway, while the original WM was a cult hit, and a good, eerie tale, helped by a wonderful score, good performances, and a brooding, unsettling atmosphere, leading to what was at the time a somewhat horrific and disturbing ending, the 2006 interpretation is a tiresome and predictable slog past Nic Cage's slack jaw. I'm not playing art-house critic snobby-guy here, either. This movie is absolutely the biggest waste of film and catering I've ever seen.I think Cage has done some good work here and there, and I know actors alone don't make movies sink or swim, but it's hard not to blame him for this. He's just...all over it. His character is gullible, stupid, and obnoxious. And we have little to look at for the duration of the film but his dopey incredulity, abrupt fits of shouting, and the endless brooding walks he takes around the island trying to figure out what is made painfully obvious to the audience, in my opinion. We're not idiots. Let us have SOME little mystery to figure out.To backtrack, Cage's character is a motor cop who picks up a doll he sees thrown from a moving car. The little brat in the back seat promptly throws it out again when he pulls over the car and returns it. As he stoops to retrieve it, a semi plows into the car, and the occupants die in flames, despite his somewhat lame efforts to save them. Of course, no bodies are recovered, he receives a letter, everyone is not who they seem, etc., etc. It's just too silly of a story-line to bore you with the details.There is a weird feminist pagan cult on an island where Cage's cop's ex-wife lures him with a letter. Kate Beahan, who is kind of hot in a waif-like way, I have to say, turns in an agonizing saucer-eyed confused-looking performance as the heroin-chic ex-wife. Any man who would believe anything this idiotic spaced-out twit said without a DNA test would not get through the police academy.The menace is heavy handed, and the clues as to the upcoming "ritual" fall like bricks. We all know the "Don't split up and look around!" sentiments horror movies have elicited for decades. This movie elicits more of a "If you can't figure it out, just go home and quit boring us!" feeling.Just a taste...crows in school desks of missing children, "our hero" punching several women in the face, full closed-fist blows, mind you. Cage's Edward (salut, Mr. Woodward) dons bear suits, commits bicycle theft against the openly hostile schoolmarm, engages in insanely stupid explorations into untenable environments where (guess what) "someone" traps him. A man who states he is fully aware he has a serious allergy to bee-stings somehow manages to ride his bike into a bee-farm and roll down a hill, caroming off hive after hive. He is alternately a bully, a spaced-out hallucinater, and a dunce. The dialog, which I shall not utter here, is beyond belief.The talented Ellen Burstyn is wasted as the sinister matriarch of the island, and given ominous, passive/aggressive lines in a final attempt to make sure even the people who were dozing, making-out, or perhaps building a ship-in-a-bottle for the first part of the movie get it. Yes, old twins and young twins, the gender structure of beehives (drones/breeders=male, workers/Queen=female...get it?). Good god, I hope so by now.Leelee Sobiesky is also a strange addition; she is sullen, rude, unhelpful, moody, and inexplicably tries to talk Edward into taking her off the island. Why? He doesn't seem to have any way to leave, and apparently she does, as we see later. You figure it out. I dare you.The Christian vs. Pagan themes that made the original WM interesting are absent. Why they want a human sacrifice is unclear. There is talk of a crop failure, but have these people ever heard of fertilizer? They're certainly aware of the modern world. And their main export seems to be honey, anyway. At least feed the sacrifice to the bees, or something. The island's cult members seem less like true-believers and more like sadistic con-artists preying on a mental-deficient.When the charming missing little girl shows up and ignites the towering wicker man with Cage's Edward trapped predictably, and almost deservedly, in harm's way, it is like watching a kitten fed to pit bulls. It is pathetic and graphic without being in any way moving.Director Neil LaBute has taken a disturbing and darkly quirky story (think Shirley Jackson's "The Lottery") and crafted something shallow and meaningless from it. It's as if the source-material were shaken upside down until all the passion and mystery and meaning fell out and then was thrown up on the screen. This film treats it's characters as dumbed-down paper cut-outs of clichés, and its audience as unable to absorb any subtlety.There is an attempt at a 'twist' or 'surprise' ending, as if everyone hadn't had enough punishment. I know my comments are scathing, but if we accept this as anything worthy of any kind of audience, we just open ourselves to the next travesty. Say NO. As I watched, I couldn't help thinking about how these millions of dollars could have otherwise been spent. Perhaps on "Stop, Or My Mom Will Shoot 2." I just can't stand it...</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2007-01-21</date>
		<username>Simon Parker</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>The Wicker Man: A Mixture of brilliance and awfulness</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I have never seen the original Wicker Man, a fact I'm not proud to admit as I am aware that it is supposedly an all time classic and containing a great performance from Christopher Lee. A shame that I never manage to catch it on TV as its a movie I desperately want to see. So when I got the opportunity to see the remake I just couldn't resist, I was aware it was hardly going to live up to the original movie, but I just wanted to see the plot and see whether the remake was actually any good at all. Remakes are funny things, for every decent one you get (Ocean's Eleven) you then go and get two along the lines of Planet of the Apes and The Grudge. So as I watched The Wicker Man I wondered what category of remake it would fall into. At first it started off quite well, in fact I was surprised as I was really getting into the movie during the first half an hour. Alas the movie then literally falls flat on its face until the last ten minutes. The dialogue while passable at first descended into horrific territory. The acting was pretty lame, Nicholas Cage practically sleepwalking throughout the movie, in fact only one person showed any sign of an effort and she was rushed off in a couple of scenes (Ellen Burstyn!). Matters aren't helped as we see some of the most ludicrous scenes I have seen in cinema history. Nicholas Cage running through a forest in a bear costume! Oh and did I mention the lamest dialogue in ages from Cage, "I think something terrible is about to happen!". While it might not sound bad written when you hear it you just want to die laughing it is executed so badly. Thankfully the ending redeems the movie quite a bit as the surprise twist and shock finale remain intact from the original (One of the few things I knew about.) Okay then the plot of The Wicker Man follows Edward Malus, a police officer who receives a message from his ex-fiancé. She lives on an old fashioned island called Summers Isle. Her daughter has gone missing and she wants Edward to help her find her. Edward himself is suffering from distress after he failed to save a mother and daughter earlier on in his career. When he arrives on the island he soon realises all is not as it seems. The island is mostly occupied by women, all of whom deny the very existence of the missing girl. As Edward investigates further he discovers mysterious cover ups aplenty and a mystery that leads to something much darker and much more ancient. As far as I am aware this is still the exact same plot as was in the original movie, in fact its actually a very good plot. The mystery element and the actual characters are always intriguing. The head of the island, Lady Summersisle is an intriguing character as is Edward's ex-fiancé Willow. I fact the only one truly dull character is Edward himself. His background story seems more forced than anything else and you really couldn't care too much for him.So what are the big problems for the movie then? Well its major problem is the editing and how poorly written it is. The first half an hour while poorly written contains atmosphere, a creepy scene where Edward investigates a barn really does send shivers up the spine. The editing here is spot on and works brilliantly. And then the director just seems to go haywire with the editing scissors. It becomes more about Edward riding a bike round the island then trying to deliver anything remotely like scares. To make matters worse when the twist does come around its done in such a silly way that its impact is dimmed slightly. The ending is still brilliantly edited and something to savour, hence why the rating of this movie is considerably higher than I suppose it would be without it.All in all The Wicker Man isn't a bad movie, in fact its a half decent one at times. Yet its lacking something to really excel it in the brilliant territory. With a dull performance by the lead, poor editing and poor writing the movie could have been a disaster. It redeems itself with the plot always standing strongly, the ending being a shocker and the actual characters on the island always being intriguing. A shame then the movie just can't live up to all expectations though. Still I now want to hunt down the original and try and compare it to this movie.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2007-01-05</date>
		<username>melody edwards</username>
		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>Insult to the original film.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The second film is completely out of context, in comparison to the British original. Edward Woodward (a theatre actor) and Christopher Lee, are two fine British actors of the highest calibre. Whereas Nicolas Cage has a limited and unconvincing stance, either as a cop or a victim in this rather shabby second version. The first film is quite a brilliant concept, the theme is built upon ideas of the ancient pre - Christian Religion. Which was discredited historically and given quite a bad name. Wicca or Paganism, as it is sometimes called was never actually started as a Devil worship. This is something that was added and deliberately connotated to make Wicca an evil concept. Some may argue, it was and still is practiced as a relatively harmless worshiping of nature and giving thanks to various god's such as the sun god and moon goddess for growth and abundance of crops. It's philosophy 'If it harm none' (basically states no harm should be done to anyone during practicing of its magic, not to be confused then, with Black Magic!) By those British and European people of very ancient and simple times. Who had by today's standards a very tough lifestyle! With no 'Mod Cons'It is common knowledge in England, and obviously something new, weird and completely unknown about in America! Who in this poor replica of 'The Wicker Man' Very cleverly or stupidly (depending on how you look at it, and from what angle) manage to totally distort and destroy the entire theme of the British Pre - Christian Cult film and its Devil worshiping connotations, which (as all educated Britians might know) was originally brought about by the early Christians, to destroy the Cult itself, rightly or wrongly.Also, the film in my opinion as a woman, is offensive to womankind. I would go so far as to say, it carries with it dangerous overt and covert messages to the viewer. It appears to be saying that for example (the scene of Nic Cage having his legs broken deliberately,by women while the 'all women coven' watch and smile and grin gleefully) That in general women are naturally unkind, cruel and insanely sadist. This is reaffirmed when the lost child in question, is encouraged by each generation in turn (Grandmother and Mother) to ignite the fire below her own father. Who incidentally she has neither met or known of til he is chosen for sacrificial purposes.I can see why Edward Woodward politely declined to partake of a role in the second film. It bears no resemblance to the first, somewhat brilliantly suggestive, historically anti - establishment and intellectually stimulating, although slow moving epic. The first film is based loosely on Factual British, theological history and does make you think deeply, if you are familiar with the facts or not!The second is sexist, rubbish, mumbo jumbo and complete and utter nonsense. I am sorry i wasted my time watching this rubbish! I wouldn't even give it a 0. It was so bad. Yes, the scenery and rural countryside was pleasant enough, but when compared to the peaceful tranquility of the Scottish location in England, no contest.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2006-12-30</date>
		<username>maelstrom1337</username>
		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>Terrible!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>&lt;&lt;&lt;&lt;&lt;&lt; SPOILER WARNING: SOME SCENES ARE REVEALED IN THIS REVIEW &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; This movie is in my lowest ten movies of all time and ultimately disappointing for a Nicholas Cage movie; normally, I'm a fan of him.First, would like to begin with the good parts of this movie, the pros. The beginning flowed well and character creation and acquaintance was smooth. I really bought the whole Nicholas Cage as a cop and going to some mysterious, private island, and I was especially intrigued with the car explosion. The scenery of Summer's Isle was beautiful and the immediate Amish sort of mysterious satanic ambiance lured the watcher further into the movie. The bloody bag right when Nicholas Cage arrived on the island got the watcher's attention.But besides the good things, there were three major flaws of this movie, in order of increasing severity.First, Sister Willow, the dumb blonde bimbo who just can't get a single word out, deflated the seriousness of the movie and sort of angered the watcher at her instead of drawing the watcher's concentration to the story at hand.Next, the Pagan feel of the movie. I understand that it is the right and fairness of the producers to make Summer's Isle of Pagan, or at least feminist, custom, but I think that it was unnecessary. By the end of the movie, I was more angry at feminists than the whole conspiracy, and on a whole I think this movie brewed hatred towards women and wrongly so.The final and most atrocious slip-up of this entire movie: the ending. If I were to make the Wicker Man into an analogy, the beginning is like setting the foundation of a card castle. Repetitively stacking countless playing cards on top of each other with phenomenal method and beauty; the end is like placing a bent card in the last place and watching this beautiful set-up crash down in a falling maelstrom of misery. Here's how the ending worked out: Nicholas Cage comes out of a Crypt after being released by Willow from some sort of pool--with a Jesus statue in it?--after which he begins to run around the entirety of Summer's Isle, looking for his supposed daughter. Barging in on peoples houses. One barging scene that I thought was particularly comical was the one in which he walks down from his room in the town tavern to find two of the "sisters" talking about the murder of the supply plane pilot. After the one leaves, the other sister begins to talk to him. He then proceeds to make a swift punch to her face, knocking her out (never seen Nicholas Cage glorification before.) Finally, Nicholas Cage finds a bear costume that he uses to disguise himself in the ritual. Once the convoy arrives at the spot of sacrifice, Nicholas Cage sees his daughter, Rowan, tied to a wooden pole and then presumes to run to the pole, deliver another mighty blow to a poor woman's jaw and run away with Rowan. The dynamic duo manage to dodge the sisters sent after them and then progress (somehow) back to the place of sacrifice where Summersisle proceeds to reveal the whole cheesy conspiracy to make Nicholas Cage come out to the island. Nicholas Cage has his legs broken and he is drawn into a giant wooden structure in the shape of a man (finally, we know what the wicker man actually is) and Rowan lights this structure on fire. Nicholas Cage, along with about ten other farm animals, are burnt to death... end. No wrap-up about Nick's random call to his partner while running from the "sisters," no wrap-up about the strange man in Sister Summersisle's bed, no wrap-up about the bees swarming the bar-maiden in Summersisle's house, no wrap-up about the bloody bag, and no wrap-up about why the men couldn't talk. That is why I gave this movie a one out of ten.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Boring</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Nic Cage goes in search of his lost daughter in THE WICKER MAN and runs afoul of an isolated community of pagans. This remake of an old Chris Lee flick has little suspense and nothing to hold the attention, as Cage literally scrambles about the countryside, thinking he has glimpsed his kid first here and then there. Some of his search becomes downright comical, especially in a scene where he is trapped overnight in a cistern. Cage's character is allergic to bees, and there's a scene involving torture-by-bees where Cage utters what is destined to become an immortal line: "Oh God, not the bees!" Ellen Bursteyn of THE EXORCIST fame is wasted here as the head of the mysterious coven, much the way veteran horror actress Alice Krige was underutilized for a similar role in SILENT HILL. Skip this one.</fullReview>

		<date>2006-10-31</date>
		<username>cofemug</username>
		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>The ends do not justify the beginnings</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The Wicker Man (2006) dir: Neil LaBute I never cared for the original The Wicker Man. I found it slow, dull and rather uninteresting, with the exception of lots of boobies.LaBute has taken the idea and made it into a Neil LaBute rant about feminism. However, the movie tells more about the creator than it does about feminism.Police Officer Edward Malus works the motorcycle beat in California when a girl and her mother are hit by a truck, and the car explodes while he tries to save them. However, the bodies are never found. Coincidentally, while he's on leave and taking meds, he receives a note from his ex-fiancée (7 years ago) whose daughter is missing, and he feels summoned to the location of Summersisle, a private island in Washington. There, he finds that the residents to be mainly female pagans who believe in femininity as God. The residents, however, make it out that the missing daughter doesn't exist. And, with an oncoming ritual of fertility to appease the Gods, will Malus be out of time before the girl is sacrificed? Edward Malus is a poorly drawn Neil LaBute male protagonist. He is the uncaring machismo male who is one-minded and full of wrath. This time, however, he is also dumb, irrational, and makes a lot of decisions out of his character. Acted by Nicholas Cage, the character loses all hope of even resembling a fully-drawn character. Nicholas Cage emphasizes every distinct mood change and irrational moment to the point of nausea.He is up against a man-hating female society led by Sister Summersisle played by Ellen Burstyn, who is still a good actress slumming it in this picture. All of the females have a distinct personality trait but not a full-fledged personality. But, this is the point.And, what a point it is. Reinforcing the idea that women are smarter than men (see The Shape of Things), The Wicker Man sends Malus to his inevitable conclusion regardless of logic and behavioral standards. LaBute adores feminism and hates men. However, he also resents male brute strength over females. He also resents female emotional strength over men. And, this cements his beliefs fully. But, his ideologies aren't even at fault here.The beginning of the movie starts out fair enough, but as the movie pushes its way down you have to make more and more leaps of faith. And then, the bad dialog comes pouring out in the final 20-30 minutes. From "I'm going to find Rowan and what I need from you is to stay out of my f---ing way!" to "Ahhhh, my legs!!" the movie gets some really silly dialog...and considering its a LaBute film, its a shame to see his talent for dialog go to pot.The big questions, however, are "Is it better than the original?" and "Is it worth it?" It is arguably worse than the original. It is vastly different and in some aspects better and other aspects much much worse. But, it isn't worth it.C-</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>It is a real shame that this disaster will likely play a part in the downfall of potentially intelligent and interesting horror films coming out of the Hollywood wasteland.The acting is nothing, the plot is not in the least intriguing (the original was suspenseful and a disorientating roller-coaster on first viewing), and there emerges simply no point or reason for this film to exist. The original is timeless.The new WICKER MAN is poorly done -- the mystery doesn't exist, the director is a "smack you in the face with contemporary issues kind of guy" with no nuance, and he's completely wrong for this film. He did well with IN THE COMPANY OF MEN, but how in the world, by any bizarre stretch, can that be connected to THE WICKER MAN? It is ludicrous! 	<review>
		<date>2006-09-12</date>
		<username>Leonie Bahri</username>
		<score>0.2</score>
		<shortDescription>O Neil, where art thou?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I love Neil LaBute, and I love the 70s Wicker Man, but it was with mounting dread that I approached this film, and I was not disappointed. Actually, having said I love the 70s version, I initially didn't see why everyone was so outraged at the very thought of remaking it. In fact, it's quite a sensible candidate for a re-imagining (as they're now so hideously called), and the story lends itself quite well to being recast amongst American cultism. Really what everyone remembers about the 70s Wicker Man is the amazing ending and Edward Woodwards fascinating performance, handily forgetting Britt Eckland's weird, porno folk music video, and the tendency for any actor cast as an islander to mercilessly chomp down on some scenery. So good choice, Mr LaBute, let's see what you make of this, I innocently thought.Good Lord, this movie is bad. It lacks any atmosphere whatsoever, and surely it can't be that hard to build suspense in a film set almost entirely on a freakish, pagan island where the matriarchal rule is so extreme that men are little more than slaves and not allowed to talk. And then all of a sudden, what should be a tract on the extremes of belief and religious fundamentalism turned into a misogynistic diatribe. "Women are evil!" is what The Wicker Man screams. Ellen Burstyn wants to kill boy babies and finish off Nicolas Cage for good measure! There's a feminist conspiracy to kill Nic Cage! And just when it couldn't look any blacker for Mr Cage, he starts punching women left, right and centre. Poor little Leelee Sobieski gets flying kicked in the stomach and left for dead. And you want to cheer! Just like when Heath and Jake get it on in Brokeback Mountain was somehow breaking a Hollywood Taboo, violence against women becomes Blockbuster eyecandy (not that homosexuality is directly comparable with hitting a woman!). "You Bitches! You Bitches!", screams Nicolas Cage at Ellen Burstyn and the mum off Six Feet Under. Serves him bloody right.And then, just when you thought it was safe to leave the multiplex comes the most ridiculous, wink-to-camera, shock ending ever. But I don't want to spoil the end for you. Neil LaBute's done a good enough job of that already.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2006-09-11</date>
		<username>laika-lives</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>Neil LaBute: Witchfinder General</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Let's try and get through this review without even mentioning the original, shall we?Neil LaBute really doesn't make things easy for himself, does he? Not only does he tackle a remake - never a popular decision - but he immediately reworks it into another of his gender-war pieces, with a dispassionate matriarchy destroying an innocent man for their own (lunatic) ends. He must thrive on the accusations of misogyny - this just smacks of deliberate provocation.Whatever LaBute's motives, however, the decision to introduce the gender aspect was a canny one. Not only does it reinvigorate the well-trodden 'isolated community' storyline, it provides an opportunity to gather together a raft of America's finest character actresses in one place; it's still relatively rare for women to predominate a cast in a mainstream American film (no, really, think about it - how many films have more than three significant female characters? How many have more than two?). So make way for Ellen Burstyn, Frances Conroy, Molly Parker, Kate Beahan, Diane Delano and Leelee Sobieski; only Robert Altman and Pedro Almodovar have had more impressive female rosters.Beahan's striking features, with her almost parodically large doe eyes, provide her with the perfect patina of Bambi-like innocence; her increasingly hesitant mannerisms are slyly pitched between ruthless manipulation and genuine distress. Sobieski seems underused, but the final shot of her, lip trembling, is unforgettable; it almost saves a totally botched final scene (the audience should feel the wheels of a ruthless mechanism beginning to turn again, but those cheesy bar-room guys seem too lightweight to suffer. A little less characterisation might have been more effective by keeping it in general terms). Delano is a memorable if unsubtle presence, although anyone who has seen the 'Randall and Hopkirk (Deceased)' episode 'O Happy Isle' might have a hard time taking her character seriously (in fact, the two productions are weirdly similar, even taking the influence of you-know-what on the episode into account). Conroy seems to be having fun as Dr. Moss, and she has a wonderful knack of seeming benign and sinister with the same facial expression. Best of all is the sublime Molly Parker, an extraordinary actress who deserves wider recognition (see, particularly, 'Kissed'). In this film, she barely seems human. Her schoolteacher is both rigid and playful, easily provoked and completely in control, the one woman on the island who seems to get a genuine malicious kick out of seeing their victim meet his fate. The sight of her in her bird-mask, cycling down a woodland lane, is enough to justify this film's existence.I'm less certain about Burstyn's performance, although her low-key queen bee may well benefit from repeated viewings (although - I have to ask - why is her make-up so damned immaculate? I find it hard to see Sister Summersisle applying lipstick whilst looking in a compact). And last but not least, the main man of the piece, Nicolas Cage, gives a really solid performance, bar one line of overplaying (see if you can spot it). I'm coming to really admire Cage - he is never, ever anything less than fully 'on', committed to his performance whatever the film. I can't think of a single uninteresting Nicolas Cage performance, which is quite a lot more than I could say about almost any of his peers.(footnote: after 'Ghost Rider', 'Next', 'Bangkok Dangerous', and 'Knowing' you might say my good will towards Cage has become a little tarnished since I posted this review...)None of this really gets past the problem that the film is short on atmosphere, and the scares are, for the most part, cheap shocks. The bee imagery is fun, although those familiar with mid-period 'X-Files' may find it a little familiar. The film does tease the unknowing quite cleverly, however - those familiar with (sigh) the original might miss that LaBute sets the audience up for a 'Jacob's Ladder'- style twist that never comes (it starts with the hero rendered unconscious in a traumatic accident, he's plagued by visions of the deceased, there are non-sequiturs and surrealism - see also 'Carnival of Souls', 'Dead End', 'Soul Survivors', even 'The Wizard of Oz' for where this might seem to be going), allowing him to slip the real knife in without arousing suspicion.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>

		<fullReview>I LIKED the Wicker man. I have not seen the original so I cannot compare the 2; yet, despite the lack of publicity that the movie got, it was better than I thought. If you like psychological thrillers or movies that you have to be paying attention too, then its a fun movie. My best friend and I saw it, it's a female empowering movie that lets you put things together and you see a different society at work.The cinematography was beautiful, the island alone is gorgeous.Don't watch this movie if you can't take it for what it is, entertainment, an a bit of a cult movie. I can see this movie becoming a movie that 20 years from now, will be compared to Children of the Corn. Nicolas Cage is a cop who is doubting himself when he gets a mysterious letter, with no postal mark; he is led to an island where the inhabitents are mostly female and where males are 'seen and not heard.' He finds the woman he was going to marry, and finds out that she left when she was carrying his child, and that little girl goes missing. He has to find her, at ANY cost.</fullReview>

It's to take one classic idea and take it in a new direction. The Wicker Man was NOT in ANY WAY a bad film, comparing it to the original, with how different it is, will lead people to think so, but it's a very good movie. It's creepy for a movie that takes place entirely in the daylight. Yes, it's predictable, very, but so what? It has a good feel to it. My worst fears were more than justified, and I can do no more than agree whole-heartedly with virtually everything that has been said in the other comments. It was a waste of money, and I wouldn't recommend anyone go see it; save your cash for watching the original on DVD or on TV. A couple of minor points: many people seem to be under the impression that Summersisle in this film was off the coast of Maine; not so, the film explicitly says it is in the N-W Pacific, and part of the State of Washington. This error could have been perpetuated from a mistake by one of the media critics. Secondly, I've heard that Edward Woodward, the police sergeant of the original, was offered a cameo role. To his eternal credit he had the foresight and wisdom to turn down the offer.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>There's nothing wrong with a suspense\mystery thriller. This had all the ingredients of a great movie. He doesn't even learn the girls true connection to him until he's already deeper than anyone should have gone given all he had to go by. It just isn't believable that a bike cop from a small canyon town is suddenly just going to go off and chase after a young girl he, in his first thoughts, had no connection to.The movie plays out well enough with a few well placed "personal worst fear" moments, coupled with those "I can't believe he's doing "x" at "y" " instances (swimming in a crypt at night? digging up a grave alone? going to and staying on that island alone?). Cage's character plays the rational and logical person smacking a bit of mainlander common sense into the crazed society, all the while displaying his contempt and apathy for their ways. He seemed to smart to be so dumb.The ending is, well, shocking to say the most. It reminds me of why all good hero's need to leave the fire-arm's at home and start carrying a sword. Sword's don't need aiming, reloading, or anything but a strong will.Pagan societies will be pagan societies. Despite the movie, The Wicker Man itself was quite impressive.A bitter-sweet taste of corrupted honey for an end.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>This is a terrible remake of what is still a rather eerie little movie. 		<shortDescription>Who's looking a fool now... or should I say bear!!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Loved the original, looked forward to the remake... It's awful.The screenwriter's thought process is clunkingly obvious... change Summerisle's harvest to Honey, and hey presto let's make the hero allergic to bees! Have him experience a horrific event at the start, and hey presto you can throw in loads of flashbacks to jolt the viewer from their slumbers. Include also the most embarrassingly obvious 'Don't Look Now' reference ever ( Nic Roeg must find it all hilarious, or utterly depressing!) and this viewer was longing to see the original again. Nothing against the director, he has a good track record, BUT he can't do creepy! This should have been remade by the team behind British comedy series The League of Gentleman... it would have been freaky! Instead we get Nic Cage dressed in a bear Suit (get it? the honey connection? Whoever wrote this is a genius!). Christopher Lee and Robin Hardy must be laughing their heads off, it's great publicity for their original and I look forward to their planned sequel of sorts 'Cowboys for Christ'.So in summary, this remake proves that the original film was a true one off, just like that final shot of the wicker man's head bowing to the sunset on cue! Who needs CGI eh?</fullReview>

		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>OK film, BUT!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Well made and flawlessly acted. Nicolas Cage is a good actor, and did all he possibly could with the script. Again well directed - But!I am no fan of remakes which are just mindless identical copies of the original,and there is nothing wrong with contemporising them, but they should understand and keep an eye on the things which make the original good. Here the script lost most of the well researched history of paganism and its rituals, in favour posh looking books and 'Buffy' style explanations. Also the ending here was weak and predictable - something the original really could not be accused of!The good acting and filming support what is a weak script, which has - unsurprisingly - Americanised the setting (thus losing the history and pagan roots ) and Hollywoodised the story (no depth and predictable, with the slack taken up by special effects and sensationalism). Hollywood please remember - Jumpiness is not the same as suspense, sudden scares are not the same as horror.In all - well acted and directed, but poorly written, losing all the good stuff from the original, but keeping the sensational, irrelevant bits in.</fullReview>

		<username>Ferg Mills</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Tepid at best.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>All in all, a rather mediocre remake of the super-campy 70s movie of the same name. Much as I wanted to enjoy this film, as I had the original, I can't help but feel that the movie would have benefited enormously from more camp, more tripped-out hippy nonsense, and a little less earnestness.I was pleased that Mr. LaBute was so reverential of the source material, but without the over-the-top campiness of the original this movie feels very vanilla.I'd like to judge this film on its own merits, without reference to the original, but to do so would be even less favourable. The plot is silly, nonsensical and labyrinthine; Mr. LaBute employs shock techniques which a ten year old could see coming; and the final scene lacks punch. This is doubly so because the explanation of the importance of the Malus character is so trite, lacking the poetic quality of the original.I must give credit for casting though, especially Ms. Burstyn, who has a pleasantly commanding presence in conversation with Mr. Cage. In spite of the fact that the social structure of the community is left somewhat undefined, (something that might have been very interesting to pursue further), it is clear that Sister Summersisle belongs in charge.In short, this film lacks all the things that made the original entertaining or frightening, while retaining all that made the original so bad.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>A feel good film. After watching you'll be convinced that even you could act in and write A grade movies!Imagine your deathly allergic to bees, so your riding through a field when you realize your in the middle of a bee farm! Of course you run head long into it, knocking over every colony you see. You get stung and it fades to back. You wake up, and the doctor says, "oh thank heavens, you've been out for hours". You grab your gun, cock it and shout, "WHERE AM I"?!That was an actual scene from the film. I mean wow.. just wow. I've read better twilight fan fiction.The character development is so poor you will actually want Nick to die at the end.Why would a grown adult, a police officer no less, bust into a class room, demand they tell you where a missing person is, then swear at all the children?! This just isn't based in reality.It feels almost like the film was supposed to be absurd (think fly kicking bar maids in the face), but this wasn't communicated to the actors, who tried to play it deadly seriously. The result is a disjointed failure at either.I haven't seen the original, but I felt that there could be a decent story beneath it, it would have just required a lot more thought, characterisation and acting. Watching this felt really did feel like reading pre-teen fan fiction. Yes you might have some good themes there, its poorly developed but given to someone competent it could really be something.</fullReview>

		<date>2012-01-08</date>
		<username>Leif Barbre Knudsen</username>
		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>Bomb remake</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>How on earth is it possible to take an intelligent script with superb dialog once made into a sublime movie ... and turn in into a bomb remake? Everything is wrong. The dialog is childish, the acting hammy, the sentiments phony, subplots stupid, the gun-waving ridiculous, the explaining speeches excruciatingly embarrassing.And for good measure the director throws in a shovelful of supernatural antics which turns out trite and awkward. Nicolas Cage is a skilled actor so how it is possible to make him act like a first year theater student is the real mystery. He has ridiculous outbursts of anger which must be due to misfired directing efforts.On the small scale two pieces of dialog baffled me. The scriptwriter and the director must regard the audience to be incredibly dumb (only an American audience or worldwide?), unable to understand what they see with their own eyes. On the pier Cage makes every effort to look like he is searching for the girl and cries out the missing girls name. But Cage has to verbally assert to himself "where is she?". Oh dear! We, the audience, would NEVER have guessed he was searching for the girl from the clumsy acting alone. Why not dispense with the big budget of making a film when the dialog is ready made for radio? The second high-school cliché is the ubiquitous "are you OK?". If somebody let go of a wind they all rush around asserting each other "are you OK?". Why won't grown- up directors leave out these school theater clichés?The final scene when the girls go pickup new victims is so heavy-handed and overly explained that it makes your toes curl.If you see yourself as a normally intelligent person, then watch this bomb only as a study of inept directing. Otherwise get the original version!</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>Edward Malus receives a letter from his former fiancée Willow, who left him years ago without any explanation, telling that her daughter Rowan is missing.Edward travels to the private island of Summerisle, where Willow lives in an odd community that plant fruits, and she reveals that Rowan is actually their daughter.Along his investigation with the hostile and unhelpful dwellers, Edward discloses that the locals are pagans, practising old rituals to improve their harvest....Is the film as really as bad as the critics and people on this site make it out to be? Well it depends which way you view it. It you watch it for what it really is, a serious movie which is a remake of a cult classic (which in my opinion, many people here hadn't heard of until this was green lighted, but not all, mind), or watch it a second time and view the film as a comedy.I guarantee you will have a better time.Cage is on complete autopilot for this and not even when he is being covered in bees, does he change his monotonous voice. 	<review>
		<date>2010-01-14</date>
		<username>VerdantGreen</username>
		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>A horrendous movie that delves into the 'so-bad-it's-good' category</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Some films are bad. These bad films usually just get forgotten about over time, however some films are just so bad that they go full circle to being good. Examples of this include Battlefield Earth, Silent Night Deadly Night 2 and perhaps the most famous of all, Plan 9 From Outer Space. The Wicker Man is one of these movies.The original 1973 The Wicker Man was a horror classic that played on some very real fears that built themselves up to an unforgettable conclusion. It was a must-see movie. This is also a must-see movie, but for different reasons. It is flat out hilarious. I have never laughed so much at a supposedly serious movie in all my life. The plot involves Nicolas Cage as a police officer investigating a missing girl case on a remote island, which follows a strange cult that incorporates human sacrifice as one of it's traditions. No originality is present in this remake, except the fact that the cult is an all-female cult who believe men are inferior. The blatant sexism here is preposterous.Nicolas Cage used to be a good, respected actor. His previous films such as Raising Arizona and Face/Off were critically acclaimed and liked by many. However in the decade of the noughties, it all went sour. National Treasure was good natured fun that audiences loved but critics hated and with films such as Gone in 60 seconds, Con Air and Knowing it was clear that his career was dwindling and this movie did for Nicolas Cage what jumping on the couch on Oprah did for Tom Cruise.Let me just give you some actual samples of dialogue from this film and yes, these are actual lines from the film: ''No, not the bees, not the bees! Aaaaaah! They're in my eyes, my eyes! Aaaaaah! Aaaaaah'' ''What you got in there(a bag), a shark or something?'' ''Off the bike. Get off the bike. (Shouting and holding gun)Step away from the bike'' This film also has the infamous ''How'd it get burned'' rant by Cage who also proceeds to punch women while wearing a bear suit. The film is worth seeing for it's comedic value. I rate it 1 out of 10 because as a horror film, it fails on almost every level. It is not scary, thrilling or suspenseful. Forget Borat, Superbad, American Pie or Hot Fuzz. For a truly great recent comedy, check out this movie, you won't be disappointed.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>This movie gets worse the more you think about it.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I watched this last night and I've been progressively feeling more frustrated since then that I have to put my thoughts to paper even though I don't think mere words can express the pain this film has put my mind through. Basically the film makes no sense, it has very little plot and is not consistent with itself, there are lots of strange or stupid things that happen in the movie that have nothing to do with the plot either directly or indirectly but appear to have been put in to give the movie a few shocks. Here are some problems with this film: 1) Entire start of movie where mother and child are burnt out in car but bodies are then missing and car cannot be identified has nothing to do with the movie. 2) The "fact" that the letter he receives from the island is not postmarked has no relevance. 3) Everything and anything to do with bees and his allergy to bees has nothing to do with the plot and is completely pointless. 4) The motivational tape he buys at the start and later looses/has stolen on the island is irrelevant filler. 5) All of Edward's flashbacks / dreams of things that "have not happened" are padding to make the movie look more interesting. 6) Introductions of random characters like "two blind crones" who then do nothing in the movie. 7) Everything to do with the flooded underground crypt which he gets trapped in, the rescued 20 seconds later has no point. 8) Why Edward does not consider the child his girlfriend had shortly after she left him could be his, but when she tells him that it is "his" he doesn't quibble. 9) They lured him to the island because their crops failed but the elaborate plan to lure him there was started 5 years before their crops failed. 10) The island being ruled by women with passive mute men as their breeding servants. Why are the men so passive, why are their multiple people who look the same. Genetic experimentation? Who knows. 11) No details are given of the islander's beliefs to explain what they do other than it's something from old Britain to explain the Wicker Man at the end. 12) Why Willow keeps changing from looking a little bit sorrowful to gleefully happy at Edward burning to death at the end. 13) The acting is generally terrible, although this may be a problem with the direction and lack of character to actually act.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2007-04-09</date>
		<username>BaronBl00d (baronbl00d@aol.com)</username>
		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>Definitely Nothing to Get Fired Up About!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Okay, this is a bad movie and for many reasons, but it has some positive points too. The pacing of the film is executed rather nicely by director Neil LaBute. The scenery is breathtaking as we visit an island supposedly cutoff from civilization(near Washington State no less), and some of the island girls are attractive. What is wrong? Well, for starters, if you, like me, are a fan of the original Robin Hardy film from 1973 then you will be bitterly disappointed as this film lacks so many of the qualities that made that film truly original and a pillar of the horror genre. Anthony Shaffer's original script was bristling with tense, suggestive moments that lead to a quite unexpected denouement. Having seen that film, I and other like viewers are not going to be shocked by the ending. We already know how it ends before we walk into the theater. So for us, the film has to raise the bar with witty dialog, innovative touches to older material, and add in some fresh, fine performances by actors of some ability. This film has virtually none of those things. The script is barren of original creativity and where it does try to be creative it fails miserably. C'mmon, an Amazonian kind of island where men are emasculated and women rule! Bees! Much of the script is filled with lots of nonsense but no passion. The script lacks passion. The direction lacks passion, and most importantly, the actors lack passion. Nicolas Cage is miscast in the Edward Woodward role. He is not able to convince us that he is really concerned by anything with his laid-back, wooden performance where emotion is demonstrated by the raising of his voice. Ellen Burstyn is okay as the "lord" of the island but quips such ridiculous dialog as to take away any credibility she might otherwise of had. The real problem for me was that the original, even when you know how it will end, had sculpted a really interesting character of depth with Edward Woodward. He had a very rigid moral compass and belief system. He was almost a symbol of Christian purity and morality. Here, Cage is none of that. He is just a man with some problems who investigates a missing girl because an old flame asks him to do so. He phones in the performance. The film does not wax philosophic about what beliefs are and what sacrifice really is. It is just a copy of a former film minus the brilliant subtext. What film remake travesty awaits us now? I don't know but do know that minds like those responsible for this film are working on more dreck like this. I too was really burned seeing this.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2007-04-02</date>
		<username>steven-raynham</username>
		<score>0.2</score>
		<shortDescription>Why?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I have gained a lot of respect for Nicolas Cage based on his previous films, but this remake just made me ask myself 'why did he bother?' If you are going to remake a film then I'd assume that you thought there was something you could add to the original, or twist it in a way that would give fans of the first a reason to like the remake. As far as I can tell the only notable changes are a shift to an obviously matriarchal society for which the symbolism of a society of bees is evident; honey harvests and the destruction of the drone to indicate fertility. The lost girl becomes the daughter to the protagonist thus giving him reason to find her (like doing the right thing is not enough), and the conviction that the protagonist had any strong belief system to revival the strong Christian faith the Edward Woodward character had in the original. In addition to this the feeling of an ancient Celtic ritualistic society just doesn't come across in the film, it feels more like a twisted 'hippy' commune run by an extreme feminist. Other than these differences the plot is exactly the same, so I ask again 'why did they bother?'</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2007-03-09</date>
		<username>carnivalofsouls</username>
		<score>0.2</score>
		<shortDescription>The slow, painful demise of the horror film</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>There is a glimmer of hope at the beginning of 'The Wicker Man'. Aaron Eckhart appears fleetingly, and one is reminded that Neil LaBute was the brilliant playwright-turned-filmmaker that made two of the best films of the nineties with 'In the Company of Men' and 'Your Friends and Neighbours', before churning out the enjoyable yet comparatively undistinguished 'Nurse Betty' and 'Possession'. All these films starred Eckhart in memorable roles, but here, as he exits the first frame of 'The Wicker Man', so does one's hope that this will be as dark and disturbing as LaBute's other self-penned material, albeit in a different genre. A playwright (Anthony Schaffer) after all had adapted Robin Hardy's novel in the earlier film, and the results were, along with 'Witchfinder General' and 'Don't Look Now', one of the most memorable British horror films of its era. The new version suffers from both LaBute's inability to direct horror, with nothing resembling atmosphere or scares, and the surprisingly dull screenplay, which could have been churned out by any Hollywood hack. Sure, he gives us a matriarchal society this time around, a concept that allows him to waste an outstanding female cast (Molly Parker, Ellen Burstyn and Frances Conroy among them), but Cage's character is so irritating and the townsfolk so bereft of menace, that most viewers will simply persevere to see how the ending is staged. And, needless to say, there is nothing in the climax to rival the impact and tragedy of the original. Not as ill-conceived as the rumored remake of 'Don't Look Now' (which, one hopes, will never come to fruition), 'The Wicker Man' will nevertheless join 'The Fog', 'When A Stranger Calls', 'Black Christmas' and countless other pointless and insipid remakes of classic horror films that should never have seen the light of day. If Rod Zombie desecrates 'Halloween', it could be the death knell for the genre.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>Croc</username>
		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>Why on earth was this dreadful remake of an original masterpiece made?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This remake of the original Wicker Man is dreadful and pointless. All the charm of the original is lost. The plot is more or less the same as the original, but crucial elements of the original (the conflict between Christianity and Paganism, the wonderful music, the eroticism, the sheer terror as the victim realises his fate, etc) are missing.This film adds nothing to the original, leaves out fundamental aspects of the original, so WHY MAKE IT??? Apart from being a dreadful film, the whole notion of re-making the original Wicker Man is equally dreadful. It's like trying to re-make the Wizard of Oz. Some films are SO unique, that re-filming them is idiotic.Don't bother seeing this LaBute catastrophe. Just get the original out on DVD.</fullReview>
