	<review>
		<date>2008-07-07</date>
		<username>johnnyboyz</username>
		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>It deserves all the flack it gets and then a little more. The Wicker Man comes off as one continuous mess further embedding greatness upon the original.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>In years to come and when people look back at certain films from certain times, this version of The Wicker Man will surely go down as one of the more pointless remakes; holding its own up there with films like Psycho and Get Carter. But it's not that The Wicker Man is a dead on arrival film that hurts the more and more you watch it, it's the other sort of 'bad' film, the sort that just feels incompetent at best; the sort that has you thinking if what is going on and how things are unfolding is really how they wanted it to all go down.The primary problem The Wicker Man has holding it back the whole time is its aspiration for success. This is an American remake of a British (or more broadly, a 'European') film from many, many years ago. The film in question brought up many issues to do with religion and had many things to say, politically, about an ever changing world and society. The film raised issues to do with what's right; who's right and tried to make a statement on the balance between new beliefs in then 1970s Britain and older, much older religious beliefs to do with the ancient world ? namely sacrifices and the dismissal of science and the attention to nature and mother Earth being the sole thing to take care of in life. But this edition of The Wicker Man updates timeframe and setting into early 21st Century America, falling pretty darned flat in the process whilst delivering a filmic experience that is unintentionally funny at best.So what's the film actually about? Policeman Edward Malus (Cage) travels to an isolated island on which a ritualistic community get by in the modern-age without phone signals or electricity. It seems the daughter of Malus' ex-partner has gone missing and Malus is the man to find her after he received a letter explaining the situation. After an opening involving a traffic accident, we get rather a quick title card flash up complete with bizarre sinister music: 'The Wicker Man' it says and the odd sensation of 'was that supposed to perhaps be scary?' lands itself for the first time. It is a feeling that does not lift. The film is a series of pratfalls and unintentional scenes that play out in bizarre and comical fashion. Along the way, Malus will beg his way onto a flight to the island when informing the pilot he was a policeman would have been enough; he will swim down darkened underwater tunnels seemingly without reason and he will be chased through woods while dressed in a bear suit.In fact, the film is so far detached from not only the original but most films in general that basic logic at times will be ignored. In the original, every scene after arriving at the island which doubled up as the pre-film credit sequence was an eerie and foreboding clue as to the fact she may exist and everyone's in on something. Here, the protagonist is needlessly given a prior tragedy which acts as a mere reason for him to have 'scary' flashbacks and other such hallucinations involving the young girl he could not save from a car crash ? notice the obvious parallel here: hero has chance to redeem oneself after prior tragic event by finding a girl on an island dystopia. But the film for the best part is a series of illogical scenes rather than strange establishments of bizarre townsfolk.Here, we get Malus messing about in a farmyard barn climbing the beams and then falling off them; we get an accidentally hilarious exchange between two people during a wood-chopping scene: the girl wood chopping wants to leave the island and sees Malus as her ticket out but it's against the rules to leave; and yet the inhabitants can come and go as they please anyway. There is a scene in a classroom in which a chicken flies out of a desk: what's it doing in there? How long has it been in there? Did they put it in there for him to find? And if so, how did they know Malus was coming and would stop at the school in the first place? Then there is the brief revelation when it appears Malus has previously had sex, completely going against why the original's antagonists did what they did and the girl Malus is looking for is connected to him more so than he first thought. Also, the way in which Willow (Beahan) maintains a 'deer in the headlights' expression throughout and constantly gets-half-way-through-a-sentence...........but then stops and allows Cage to finish it for her. That grated on me very quickly. There is also the rare instance in the film of a 'dream within a dream' sequence. I haven't seen one of them in a while. The scene in which Cage swims down into a watery abyss for absolutely no reason other than he has a 'hunch' the girl might be down there and then gets locked in overnight has to evoke laughs of some sort.Then there is the climax which is ruined in the first place by way of having seen the original. Rather than sacrifice someone INTO the ground so that the crops may grow back OUT of it, the theory on this American Summersisle is that you sacrifice someone into the ground so that BEES, which are of a third party nature, will begin to re-produce honey like they used to. Where's the logic of killing someone so that something completely unconnected with what you're doing MIGHT begin to do what they're supposed to do, once again? I don't know, maybe using the word 'logic' is a bad move here but for sure, the epilogue at the very end proves that the cycle of sacrifices (and idiocy) will not stop any time soon in this crazy (or downright stupid) little community.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>

		<date>2008-03-31</date>
		<username>ozmarky</username>
		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>A Waste of Film</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>At this point in entertainment history saleability has become the leading factor in determining a project's go ahead. Every successful film of the last 40 years (even those of Asia and Europe)is being remade and mostly with disastrous results. Of all the hideous reinterpretations of recent years The Wicker Man takes the prize for the worst. The original 1973 film is a believable masterpiece with a setting, although a fantasy, that has an authenticity due to it having drawn on a real history. The re-make is a misguided attempt to relocate this historically founded story to a country that isn't old enough to have had such beliefs. The entire symbolism of the original is lost. Blind faith, virginity, ignorance, self-righteousness and temptation lead the original cop through the maze of experience to prove his worthiness. Nicholas Cage has none of these traits and is just a pawn in a ludicrous plot. The only good thing about this film is it has rekindled people's desire to see the original again and experience it's hypnotic charm.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2007-10-06</date>
		<username>Robert J. Maxwell (rmax304823@yahoo.com)</username>
		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>Travesty</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Well, they did it again. Took a little gem of a movie and remade it in the usual way -- bigger stars, more special effects, and thoroughly dumbed down so that the kind of minds of the targeted audience, which is evidently judged to be of the same caliber as the producers, won't be subject to the stress of either waiting or thinking.As far as I could tell, before I had to shut it off and run for the Pepto-Bismol, the story is roughly the same. A police investigator comes to an isolated place to investigate the reported disappearance of a young girl.In the original, the villagers tolerate the outsider (Nicholas Cage here) and treat him with polite evasiveness edged with a bit of impatience, the way you might deal with a child who keeps asking where babies come from. It's an odd attitude -- wrong, but only subtly wrong. Here, the villagers are openly hostile from the beginning. Cage (as Officer Malus) manages to get a room at the village inn but it's accompanied by the remark, "Well, if you won't take a hint -- ". If the goal is anything like that in the original, this is not only over-obvious, it actually militates against the villager's success.Much of the sex and theology of the original is toned down, at least as far as I could tell. The sergeant is no longer a virgin, nor is he very religious, for instance. (How could Nicholas Cage possibly be a virgin?) It was hard enough to believe that the original investigator (Edward Woodward) was a virgin -- but that is precisely what made him suitable for the role he was to take in village affairs, his staunch and unyielding Scottish Presbyterianism. Of course Nicholas Cage is an easier character for a modern audience to identify with, and Cage does a good job. Perhaps it's a minor quibble that one of the original's chief plot points is sacrificed so that we can now more comfortably put ourselves in the cop's unambiguous shoes.Here are a few more notes, then I'll quit. (1) This does not happen in the original, but Cage spots a girl at night who seems to be the missing youngster, chases her into an old barn, investigates with only a flashlight, falls through the floor of the loft and hangs by his fingers over a forest of upright pitch forks. Unlike the implements, the scene is pointless. (2) In the original, Woodward is quizzing an elementary school class and investigates the missing girl's empty desk. Lifting the top, he finds a beetle tethered to a string to a nail in the center of the otherwise empty space, so the beetle is slowly crawling round and round, tightening the thread around the nail. Woodward registers surprise and disgust and remonstrates with the class over their cruelty. In this one, Cage opens the lid of the desk, the music shrieks, and a great big black bird flaps out into his face in a series of rapid cuts. Instead of an off-kilter but thoroughly plausible event, you get a cheap shock. (3) Not in the original. Cage strolls to the end of a pier and sits down. Then he notices the body of a drowned blond girl locked in a cage under the water. He strips off his jacket, dives in, and brings the body of Rowan Woodward out of the cage and onto the pier, where he holds it in his dripping lap. Then -- "HUH?", and he shakes his head. It was all a daydream. (4) Not in the original. Cage walks into a field and is attacked by bees -- as in "The Swarm," "The Killer Bees," et al. (5) The original music by Paul Giovanni, at once sprightly, bawdy, and ominous, is replaced with a by-the-numbers mystery score straight out of a computer archive labeled "Mystery Music."By the way, did the movie end happily? It should have. The mystical tragedy of the original just wouldn't fit on this pandering piece of junk. On the other hand a happy ending would deprive the remake of another crack at shocks and violence. On the bright side: I think this movie gave me an idea though. How about a remake of "Citizen Kane" with Brad Pitt? No? Okay, then. How about remaking "Battleship Potemkin," only instead of rebellious Russian sailors we make them honest cops, and instead of Tsarist soldiers we make them a gang of international terrorists who speak with German accents? I see Keanu Reeves in the lead, with Angelina Jolie as the love interest.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2007-02-16</date>
		<username>fwomp</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>A Guilty Pleasure</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Leveling off at an extremely chilly 14% approval rating on Rottentomatoes.com, THE WICKER MAN got pummeled by critics large and small. Some called it "over-the-top" while others mentioned its unbelievability factor. Both criticisms are correct, but that doesn't mean that The Wicker Man isn't a guilty pleasure for some viewers ...like me.Nicholas Cage (WORLD TRADE CENTER) stars as Officer Edward Malus, a beat cop who one day stops a car that had a doll fall from its window while speeding along a desolate highway. When Edward returns the doll, the little girl in the back seat again tosses it back onto the road. Edward goes to pick it up again and while he's scooping it up, a semi smashes into the car on the shoulder, eventually killing both the driver/mother and the daughter in the backseat.Haunted by this horrible event, Officer Malus seeks refuge at home whenever he can. But a letter soon arrives from a lost love named Willow (Kate Beahan), beckoning him to come to her at a place called Summersisle in Washington State. The letter goes on to say that Willow has had a child named Rowan (Erika-Shaye Gair, RV) that has mysteriously disappeared.Once on the island of Summersisle, Edward quickly surmises that all is not right here. Women rule the place and the few men present are docile. He also notes (with a hint of sarcasm) the tree-ish first names of all its residents (the aforementioned Rowan and Willow, along with Beech and several other colorful names).Willow, Edward's lost love, finally tells him that Rowan is his daughter, thus pumping up his need to find her, dead or alive.As the minutes tick by, Edward discovers a strange cult-like following, almost Druid in fashion, that stretches from one end of this small island to the other. Was Rowan a victim of some sort of ritualistic demagoguery? Was she sacrificed and burned alive? Nicholas Cage has never been one of my favorite actors, but he is entertaining at times. His part in LORD OF WAR was one of his more recent acting successes. Here in The Wicker Man, he's entertaining, too, if often times a bit over the top (as the critics have pointed out...the obvious part being the now infamous bee helmet scene where he screams, "What is that?! Oh bees! Bees! They're in my eyes!").Probably the biggest boost for the film is that its pacing is done pretty well, gradually ratcheting up the tension as the story progresses. The ending is also a bit of a shocker, especially the leg breaking scene that nearly made me nauseous, and brought to memory the Kathy Bates bit in MISERY.The whole premise, however, is pretty faulty. The Druids never made it to America, but some of their fans certainly did later on (much later on). There's also the fact that Edward (Cage) is a cop, and if a cop went missing for any length of time, people would start looking and asking questions.Even so, if you force yourself to ignore these blatant oversteps, you might find The Wicker Man a guilty pleasure, like chocolate syrup on a rapidly melting sundae.P.S. Much has been made of the fact that this film is a remake of Anthony Shaffer's 1973 film by the same name starring Christopher Lee and Edward Woodward. Not having seen this version, I can only comment on the story seen in this updated version</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Why oh Why Did Hollywood Bother To Remake ?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I put down my $9 at the kiosk and sauntered off to the designated screen for what I had hoped was a fantastic remake of a true classic. But saddened I was to see that yet again Hollywood had failed to produce a remake worthy of the former film's name.Questions1. Why did I fall for this ruse? 2. Why did I waste 3 hours of my life? 3. Why did I waste $9 (as well as the price of popcorn and gas) ?I'm not sure i can offer anything good to say about this film. The acting was stale, predictable and glassy, especially Nick Cage, who in my opinion has yet to deliver a role worthy of his profession. The cinematography was poor and the screenplay was broken.The original 1973 version continues to be exciting, memorable and has aged very well indeed. Cut to the chase, get a copy of this from your local store (or Netflix) and make your own popcorn for a home viewing.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2006-09-03</date>
		<username>Dave_Violence</username>
		<score>0.2</score>
		<shortDescription>Don't cry over spilled honey...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I just saw it... In New York city, utilizing the Fandango web service (you never know if these things will sell out or not), I paid $12.50 to see this film.On a scale of $1 to $12.50, the new "The Wicker Man" is somewhere between $1 and $2.50. HUGE SPOILERS AHEAD.OK, as a "Wicker Man" purist, at first I didn't want to even know a remake was to be released. Why mess with perfection; what's been done has been done: it's not a play or serial that's meant to be redone. Plus, the only person you could get to replace Christopher Lee would be Christopher Lee. Nevertheless, assuming it's done well, I could see the story translating really well to a U.S. setting, with some old cult, well-isolated, well-insulated, still practicing that Old Time Religion...Sure it's derivative! What isn't? Well-told, this story always packs a wallop and is solid, horror fun. The original Wicker Man has a disturbing, unresolved, unhappy ending. The story doesn't close (what happens next? who knows?!) and that's it's lasting effect: will Lord Summerisle be sacrificed if the next crop fails as Inspector Howie cries out in hopeless desperation? Good question, but you'll never know because the film is over.Not this Wicker Man, though. In general casting terms, OK, Nicholas Cage is good. His character of Edward Malus (ohhh! "Edward" chasing Rowan "Woodward" - nice, and Malus? As in "Malleus Maleficarum?" What a clever touch!) has plenty of attitude but he lacks the religious stick up his ass that Insp. Howie had. That was essential to the story because it established genuine antagonism between Howie and the Summerisle cult. Howie's a Roundhead flunky for all it matters and he's up against the Druid of Druids. Tough luck for the Roundheads... Cage's character, without question a typical, modern American agnostic can only look to cheap, truck-stop self-help books to fight his inner demons and probably could care less what a bunch of hippie, whack-jobs believe in.Ellen Burstyn. For the sake of argument, I couldn't think of a better choice. She has serious horror movie credibility. And she can take charge of the scene - like her character's supposed to.Plot holes: OK, so the switch is from crops in general to honey. OK, so the Summersisle cult is really a colony of bees with multiple, fertile queens with an uber-queen at the head (Burstyn). No problem, makes for an interesting story, sort of like a reverse of L. Sprague de Camp's "Rogue Queen." Well, then, why not run with that story? Let's say that Nick Cage is now on the island - get him to replace the old man in charge of shagging the non- menopausal queens! Throw the old guy into the Wicker Man and be done with it!No, no... We're going to try and match the original movie line-for-line, make-up nuance for make up nuance, costume for costume... and it didn't work. Howie's research made it clear why the folks were in costume. All Cage/Woodward's "research" did was determine that a) the cult aborted most of the males (why? Not good enough? The men hanging around were weaklings - why not explain it some more?), and b) someone conveniently left out a manual on ritual human sacrifice - too easy. I must give credit though: the scene with the aborted male fetuses in jars was disturbing, disturbing at the right "Wicker Man" level, yet the film just didn't run with it. Make Cage burn with right-to-life anger; let's hear the Summersisle girls explain their pre-emptive patricide, give the story some interesting, provocative, controversial dialog. Make the audience uncomfortable - instead, there were regular laughs from the audience.Why are the women chanting "The drone must die"? Did he finish fertilizing the "colony"? Apparently, he fathered one - but is that enough? Is Willow to be the next queen? Will Rowan then follow in her footsteps? If they're the royal line, don't they need more heirs? We saw multiple pregnant girls? Was it all the old man in the bed's work? Did Cage's character do anything that would distinguish himself a drone other than being a man?Annoyances: why is a waitress in California talking like some stereotypical "southern" dunce (using "them" instead of "those"? That didn't make sense.Cheap film: Is the audience so stupid that Cage has to scream "my legs!" so we'll all know that the Queen Bee's minions have broken his legs - off camera? Why not have Sister Summersisle say "bind his legs!" or "break his legs!"? Or similar? And why'd they kill the pilot? That, if any action would bring the entire State of Washington police "swarming" all over the island? They didn't even get rid of the evidence well enough! A flight plan was probably filed! The guy might have a family! There's an oil slick on the water! What about other people who needed use of the plane? There's bound to be an investigation, ladies!I want my money back part: The epilogue, "six months later" - what the hell? Now the Summersisle cult goes out hunting men? For what? If they'd kept Nick Cage drugged up or gave him some special potion to "keep it up," they'd be saved all the trouble. Double I want my money back: the film is dedicated to Johnny Ramone - who, no doubt is rolling in his grave. I didn't hear any punk rock music in the film...Four people (two couples) walked out of the movie. One couple left about forty minutes into things (I figured they just didn't get it and were bored). The second couple left after just over an hour - that I didn't get: weren't they interested in how it ended? The theater wasn't crowded, it was an evening show, on a weekend.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2006-09-03</date>
		<username>LadyLiberty</username>
		<score>0.2</score>
		<shortDescription>The Wicker Man a Hollow Experience</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>In The Wicker Man, Edward Malus (Nicolas Cage) is a cop. During the course of a routine traffic stop, there's a terrible accident that injures him and leaves him helpless to rescue a mother and her daughter from a fiery death. Far worse than his physical injuries are the nightmares ? occurring both when he's asleep and awake ? involving the people he couldn't save. So when a letter arrives from a woman he loved years ago, he's all but helpless to refuse her plea for assistance in finding her missing daughter.So Malus travels to Summersisle where Willow (Kate Beahn) now lives. He has a difficult time getting to the secluded island, and once there, is viewed with a good deal of suspicion by the island's mostly female inhabitants. Willow, who is called Sister Willow by the other women, takes him aside and warns him that the others will lie to him. But she also emphasizes what she believes to be looming danger to her missing daughter Rowan (Erika-Shaye Gair).Malus fuels his search for Rowan not only with his memories of his old relationship with Willow but with his anguish over his inability to save another little girl from her fate. He needs that commitment since he finds his efforts thwarted at virtually every turn by women who are hostile at best, and who look him in the eye and lie as a matter of course.Sister Beech (Diane Delano reluctantly offers him a place to stay, but remains leery of the California cop. Sister Rose (Molly Parker) is a teacher who expends most of her energies teaching her charges lessons with which Malus thoroughly disagrees. Dr. Moss (Frances Conroy) seems willing to care for everyone ? even Malus ? but she also comes across as evasive, which causes Malus to become more determined than ever to get to the bottom of the mystery.Malus finally has the opportunity to meet the woman in charge of the isolated community. In a conversation with Sister Summersisle (Ellen Burstyn), Malus' internal alarm bells are ringing louder than ever. But he ignores his intuition in the hopes of saving Willow's daughter and thus redeeming himself. What Malus doesn't realize, of course, is that the dangers on Summersisle extend far beyond the life of one missing little girl...Nicolas Cage is typically a capable actor, even when he's saddled with a less than optimal script. In the Case of The Wicker Man, background information has it that Cage was so affected when he viewed the original that he promoted the remake. Perhaps he thought better of it as filming commenced, though, because his performance here is all but phoned in. Every emotion is heightened to the point of melodrama in an episode of "bad acting theatre;" every facial expression is both stereotypical and exaggerated.Frances Conroy is fine, and Molly Parker is just terrific. Supporting cast members Leelee Sobieski and Diane Delano are also all right (though Sobieski is miscast in a role that requires a far more delicately pretty woman than she is). Ellen Burstyn is thoroughly wasted in a part that sees her spew some of the most godawful lines ever penned in a movie with a budget, while Kate Beahn is just plain godawful (if there's somebody else out there who can speak more woodenly, or convey less emotion despite huge, doe-like eyes, I don't know who she might be).The greatest insult to audiences (not to mention fans of the original movie), though, is a really bad screenplay. Director Neil LaBute penned the script, which is based on the original by the late Anthony Shaffer. While his direction is largely okay, and the cinematography spectacular, the script is rarely less than implausible, and it often crosses the line into the just plain ridiculous. Though the movie begins with some promise with the grave psychological impact of the accident the lead character witnesses, it quickly devolves into a series of utterly predictable and entirely unbelievable events.The bottom line: Think about renting the original (again, I can't recommend it not having seen it, but a lot of people who have seen it do), and don't even think for a moment about seeing the 2006 remake. It's not worth even the price of a ticket let alone the time you'll never get back.POLITICAL NOTES: One of the most ham-handed plot devices in The Wicker Man involves what is apparently an isolated community of witches (though the words "pagan" or "Wiccan" are never mentioned, there is a reference to Salem as well as to various medieval pagan ceremonies and celebrations that imply strongly that that's what they are). Every witch that I know ? and I do know a few ? would be appalled by vast majority of the actions depicted in The Wicker Man. Unfortunately, there are those devout fundamentalist Christians who would take every opportunity to condemn pagans as minions of Satan. Though they're wrong, films like The Wicker Man will give them the unneeded opportunity to gloat, "I told you so!" FAMILY SUITABILITY: The Wicker Man is rated PG-13 for "disturbing images and violence, language, and thematic issues." In the case of portions of the story line, PG-13 may actually be a little weak though none of those thematic issues are visually depicted in an R-rated manner. If you've got kids who insist on seeing The Wicker Man because it's being billed as a horror film (the most horrific thing about it is the movie itself rather than the plot per se), I'd deny unqualified permission to kids of 14 or so and younger. As for the rest, well, the good news is that you can always tell them that you told them so after they've been as duly disappointed as I was by this dud.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2006-09-02</date>
		<username>tfc</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>They don't make Wicker Mans like they use to. Oh well, watch it anyway, it's different.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Concerning the new remake of the Wicker Man (WM)(2006), let's get the 500-pound gorilla out of the way first, the Wicker Man (1973). Having seen the first Wicker Man (1973) numerous times and wearing out the CD. It has qualities that make it unique to the point where both movies need to be judged on their own merits because they are different (frankly the 1973 version has a better twist on being twisted, thus is better IMHO). It's kind of like comparing Lost Horizon (1937) (a drama) with Lost Horizon (1973)(a musical). I could also wax poetic about the many differences to fill a book, but that is really a waste of everyones time nitpicking. Nevertheless, purge your mind totally of the WM 1973 version and watch the WM 2006 version it's a fair movie that has some interesting plot twists that make the new WM worth a watch.Quick Plot Summery: A police officer fails to rescue a woman and her little girl from a burning car and is put on medial leave from the trauma. The officer later receives a letter from a long ago ex-fiancée, who returned home to a secluded esoteric commune on Summersisle island in the northwest US. Her daughter is now missing and she, fearing the worse, pleads for the officer's help to locate her daughter. The officer goes to Summersisle, only to discover a matriarchal (female centered) commune more in tune with the old ways (pagan), free from the "normal" world's repressions. Summersisle's main cash export is honey, but last years honey production was "cursed" for the first time in many years and the missing girl was blamed. During his stay, the officer gets the picture that he is wanted like the plague and receives very little help. While making his investigations, the officer comes to the conclusion that the missing girl will be sacrificed in a pagan ceremony to ensure a bountiful harvest in the future. The officer tries to rescue the missing girl, only to find that he was being played a fool from the start of the movie in a twisted game of cat and mouse. It seems the commune does not sacrifice their own, but outsources the honor to outsiders and the officer now has that honor. You need to see the movie to see what befalls the officer and the recruiting of new sacrifices for the commune.Interesting Points: The commune is modeled on one big happy bee hive. The women are the "worker bees," the men are the "drones" and there is one "queen bee." Little if any technology used by the commune. Low tech.The commune is not based on traditional Christian values, which throws the officer off balance.The scenery is peaceful, beautiful, simple, and clean which is the icing that covers the hard, rigid, chess like calculating, but maniacal nature of the commune.Disappointing Points: Sometimes the plot drags and several scenes that did not add much to the plot were stuck in to increase the weird factor.Yes, we get all the many, many points that the commune is based on a bee hive, now get on with the plot. The bees covered nude girl on a chair really clarified everything . . . not.Frankly, the whole car crash and burn scene at the beginning could be eliminated IMHO. I would have had the officer officially visit the island to investigate the missing child to save time at the film's start.The officer does not seem to conduct himself in an official manner. Beating up several women, holding a gun on a petite bicycle riding school teacher, and waving around a badge like a fan seems like over kill. By the time the officer makes it to the end of the movie, you start to sympathize with the communes actions and wonder if the police department will even care if this officer comes up missing.All the flashbacks and hallucinations wear thin after a few times, especially when they do not help the plot. If you want weird, then show weird. Many of us movie goers do not know what May poles are for and what pagans believe, so a little hint or two would have make the movie less boring and add true strangeness.I now know why the commune has an "only outsider can be sacrifices" rule. If I lived in the commune long enough, I would volunteer as the next sacrifice just to break the monotony. And you thought the "normal" outside world was repressing the spirit.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>This movie is OK! ( This was a review written by me in a news paper in NorthEast Philadelphia)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>In the middle of the night, and rain pouring outside....a movie called "The Wicker Man" was reviewed. This movie is full of bull **** when it says its scary or anything related. Yet this movie is weird. The Wicker Man, starts out with a man, he tries to save a girl from an accident but it blows up, supposedly killing the little girl and mother. After 6 months or so, Hes taking drugs and seems very depressed. Then he gets a letter from this woman, saying her daughter is missing and that shes his run away engagement. He goes to find this girl, which is on a private island. Once there the movie begins. But it sucks. There are too many scenes where he is running around, too less scenes of something scary or that would progress the story. And in watching this movie, the characters kept changing the story around about the where abouts of this little girl, and i could tell the man was very annoyed and confused too. This movie doesn't bring anything to the table accept screaming at the end. The only problem with this movie was it was too funny. It had stupid scenes where this guy would see someone that had been torn in half, eyes missing, and mouth tied shut, and he still shakes him to see if hes alive.It had good photography and thats what I will say is only good. I also think this movie is too crazy to even take seriously, because if someone runs away from somewhere, gets engaged and loves being out of the place she once was, who in the hell will believe she would go back. Its a good date movie with laughs and occasional jumps and scares, yet it just isn't that good of a movie for those die-hard horror moviegoers.The only thing i can say about the guy in this movie and his stupidity, shame on you! I give this movie 2 out of 4 stars.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2006-09-02</date>
		<username>nqure</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>Watch the original</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>A dreadful disappointment for a number of reasons: uneven pacing, a miscast lead, the lack of subtlety, loss of (religious) context and beautiful soundtrack from the original, as well as elements of misogyny: the audience I saw the film with laughed when Malus (Cage) punches women towards the film's denouement. And here lies one of the film's greatest flaw. In the original, you suspended your disbelief as Lord Summerisle, an Aleister Crowley type figure, dominates proceedings. Anyone with a knowledge of pagan religions would realise that women are creative, nurturing forces in nature.The film fails on so many levels. I went in with an open mind, hoping it would be better than I anticipated but I realise why so little publicity was released beforehand. Because it is a huge, leaden disappointment.There are some interesting scenes: the old women who greet Malus like the witches from Macbeth, the blind sisters. The film does possess some frightening moments (the barn &amp; the cellar in the darkness) but it is reminiscent of a Stephen King film, a trip on a fright ride and detracts from the genuine foreboding and creepiness of the original.The bee motif is interesting up to a point but overplayed though it was a clever idea to have Malus lured to the island as part of some deliberate plan to secure a male sacrifice. But the original made more sense. Why is it so hard for an audience to imagine the policeman as a virgin? In fact, a possible reworking by Robin Hardy of the original set in contemporary Scotland has two members of the Silver Ring Thing become involved with a pagan community.However, the few pluses barely make up for a poor script/reworking and it is damning that many of the best scenes are those based on the original. There are also so many plot holes. Why murder the pilot of the flying boat? Why not simply render the character as a woman who is party to the plot? In fact, I laughed when Malus is finally confronted with his fate. LaBute even contrives to reduce what should be a horrific moment with a trace of farce as Cage whines 'If you think this is going to save your god-damned honey'. The ending in the original is so powerful precisely because of Howie's faith and his genuine terror. Cage, like me, seems to welcome his fate because it puts out us of our misery.A word of advice to anyone financing a remake by Neil Labute or anyone in Hollywood, like the Ring franchise. Don't bother. And if Stateside audiences are too lazy to watch the originals either because they look dated or are in subtitles, then they really do lack imagination.As someone British, please try not to ruin more of our classic films. I shudder to think what a US studio would do to 'Black Narcissus'. Probably have Scarlett Johannsen as Sister Clodagh writhing on the ground in a passionate embrace with George Clooney as Mr Dean whilst mad Sister Ruth played by Jessica Alba flagellates herself naked.Be careful, a UK studio like Ealing might remake 'Casablanca' starring Hugh Grant. You have been warned.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2015-06-10</date>
		<username>jlthornb51</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A Visionary Director Courageously Reinterprets a Classic Film</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Visionary director Neil LaBute has fashioned a motion picture that is not a remake but a beautifully realized personal interpretation of the original source material. Sensitively observed and carefully crafted, this is a film that is breathtaking in its imagery and quite disturbing in its haunting surrealism. An outstanding cast is uniformly excellent and the characters in this story are as gripping as they are fantastical. Nicolas Cage gives one of his finest performances in a role fashioned originally by the great Edward Woodward and Cage manages to make that iconic character uniquely his own. LaBute's depiction of a sinister alien culture is accentuated by his creation of a heavy atmosphere of fear, dread, and ultimately overwhelming terror. He takes tremendous risks with his reinterpretation of the classic film and they pay off spectacularly. Courageous artistic choices and creative vision make this Wicker Man a stunning motion picture experience.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2008-04-06</date>
		<username>philpaine</username>
		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>They Didn't Have a Clue</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Whoever was responsible for this abomination didn't have the slightest idea what the original film was about. The original was an intelligent study of the tension between ancient Pagan and Christian values, done with wit and irony. This remake is a laughable travesty written by somebody who knows absolutely nothing about either Christianity OR Paganism. Every key concept in the original is missing, or garbled. The most important aspect of the pagan culture (that it delights in nature and sex, and is joyous and festive --- beautifully portrayed in the movie) is completely absent. The pagans are portrayed as grim, shuffling fanatics, instead. In the original, the point is that the policeman, while he is stiffly pious and puritanical, nevertheless faces his martyrdom bravely, sincere in his faith. You are supposed to laugh at him in the beginning, but slowly come to respect him in the end. All of this was completely over the heads of the nitwits who made this remake. How could this have even gotten off the ground as a project? The real horror is that a classic film has been remade by complete idiots. For that kind of sacrilege, it would be nice if human sacrifice was still an option.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2006-09-01</date>
		<username>rivertam26</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>wannabe weirdos...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The Wicker Man "2006" is a strange movie and not in the way the 73 version was strange. I'm sure on paper the whole thing sounded great. Giving the film a hyper feminine twist and make it more accessible by casting a big star and throwing in some punch lines. It must have also sounded great to have this remake directed by Neil Labute famous for his films that have strong female leads and feature the dissection of men. But on screen it just doesn't work. It's no surprise that Labute has no experience in the genre and it's just a one of the films many problems. Cage stars as Edward Malace a highway cop who supposedly becomes involved with a horrific accident that claims the lives of a young girl and her mother. While on leave he gets a letter from his ex fiancée bidding him to come and help her find her daughter who has gone missing. Against the advice of his friends he travels to the mysterious island filled with people who worship gods and goddesses, make sacrifices to ensure a good harvest and dress up as animals. He pokes around the island a bit, and everyone is fitfully weird until that dreaded, somewhat disturbing but clichéd conclusion. This version of that classically creepy film is strange for the fact that it tries so hard to be strange while remaining mainstream. It has the oddball dancing, disturbing imagery, weird dialogue and cultish festivities but it lacks being involving. And in a film like this it must be involving otherwise it comes off as being unintentionally funny. Which it is, it's a laugh riot. there is not one genuinely creepy or suspenseful sequence within the entire film. All the characters are one dimensional giving questionable performances. And the plots pacing and direction give one pause when assuming the films credibility. The biggest thrills come from Cage knocking out women and jump kicking them in the faces. The 3 things this film has to offer are (1) gorgeous cinematography, (2) a creepy if slightly under developed performance by Ellen Burstyn and (3) a reminder that Cage is an attractive man. Even in his older years he still retains his hard physique and chisseled face. He is always the hero, the good guy, succeeding to a fault. Besides the direction, pacing performances and screenplay what the films ultimate problem is , is that just tries too hard. If a film is weird, it's just weird. You can't try to be weird it comes off as fake. And everyone associated with this project from Labute to Cage to Sobeski is just not weird. There is no doubt that talent went into this film, but talent doesn't guarantee a good movie. And with a little less tampering and a lot more originality this could have been a truly compelling take on the original. What remains is an unintentionally funny, wannabe weirdo flick...and thats not really very appealing to anyone.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2006-09-05</date>
		<username>hpwest-1</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>The cerebral madman...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The only thing more upsetting than the horrible mis-marketing of The Wickerman is the audience's complicity in going along with it. I'm instantly reminded of another movie called Hellcab. Everything about it sucks but the movie itself. The title. The box. The tagline: "Do you dare to pay the fare?" But again, the movie itself ? very good. Go rent it.Here lies the problem: Not every film fits into a nice, little box. Not every film can be summed up. Drama. Horror. Comedy. Romance. Some films walk the line. Other's eschew it altogether. Such is the case with The Wickerman. A strange, almost Lynchian film about a man who receives a letter from a long lost love begging his help in recovering her missing daughter. Sound like an interesting premise? It is. He goes to the island and is confronted by a strange matriarchal society of strong women and mute men and searches for the girl who everyone else claims either never existed or is dead. The mystery doubles upon itself as he suffers hallucinations, vivid nightmares, and scorn from the estrogen empowered populace. Anyone familiar with Labute's previous work will understand and revel in the battle-of-the-sexes subtext. What it means exactly is up to the viewer to decide. Women are evil? Men are being castrated by an increasingly PC society? Pick your poison and drink it. Because ultimately what we have here is not the dime-a-dozen horror flick the studio machine seems to want us to think it is. Instead Labute and company have crafted an enjoyably creepy, diabolically clever forum for debate while keeping tongue firmly planted in cheek and never losing track of their source material.This is a movie highly recommended for thinking viewers and those looking for something more than a few forgettable scares.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Terrible, Shameful and Unnecessary Remake</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>While recovering from a tragic accident on the road, the patrolman Edward Malus (Nicolas Cage) receives a letter from his former fiancée Willow (Kate Beahan), who left him years ago without any explanation, telling that her daughter Rowan is missing. Edward travels to the private island of Summerisle, where Willow lives in an odd community that plant fruits, and she reveals that Rowan is actually their daughter. Along his investigation with the hostile and unhelpful dwellers, Edward discloses that the locals are pagans, practicing old rituals to improve their harvest, and Rowan is probably alive and being prepared to be sacrificed. When he locates the girl, he finds also the dark truth about the wicker man.The original "The Wicker Man" of 1973 is a simple and original dark story with a surprising end that hooks the attention of the viewer until the very last scene. This unnecessary remake is terrible and shameful, and Neil LaBute spoiled the magnificent 1973 screenplay. First, Nicolas Cage is unrecognizable, histrionic, performing an unpleasant and abusive character, punching women, interrupting a class without any education and so on. There are many ridiculous scenes, like for example with Edward Malus digging a grave or diving into the water wearing shirt, tie and jacket. The good cast is wasted in a laughable and boring flick, actually an insult to the wonderful British film. In my opinion, it is better off watching again the original movie and forgets this silly remake. My vote is three.Title (Brazil): "O Sacrifício" ("The Sacrifice")</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2006-08-31</date>
		<username>AlanJ2</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>A far better and more ambitious remake of a classic than the disastrous 'Omen'</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Beautifully visualised with some excellent sequences and a strong central performance from Cage, this new 'Wicker Man' deserves much credit for rethinking and reworking the original rather than just regurgitating it like the recent remake of 'The Omen'. Be warned though that many of this film's better sequences are in its trailer and you will enjoy it much more if you haven't seen the trailer. There are also loose ends, and things that don't tie up properly, which leave the viewer feeling slightly cheated. But the overall conception is wonderfully creepy with the Paganism of the original being given a feminist spin which ties in with the theme of 'The Da Vinci Code' Given the fact 'The Wicker Man' is a hard film to remake, this has enough originality and power of its own both to reward fans of the first and engage those who never saw it.Given the slightly hostile reception to this movie and one extraordinarily unfair and grossly inaccurate review in 'Variety' I'd like to add a few words to the above. The film is being condemned firstly by fans of the original, secondly by people who hate this kind of film anyway. The two types are very different but have merged into an unholy chorus (fuelled by beefs about the soundtrack which are a complete red herring). If only they had done this for the vastly inferior 'Omen' remake which really was a lazy and cynical disgrace. By contrast here enormous care has been taken to rework the story from scratch. None of the detractors are giving any credit at all to the film's first half which is entirely different from the earlier film and intelligently so.Indeed the reviewer in Variety appears to have forgotten the plot of the first 'Wicker Man' altogether for he seems to think no changes have been made of any substance! Let me remind him that in the first film the hero was just a dogged ordinary policeman doing his somewhat routine duty. Here Cage is a man returning to find a lost love and his own lost child after an electrifying and very strange opening involving a horrifying encounter with a woman and child who are killed before his eyes. The brutal fact is, Variety, that up to the halfway point this is a completely different movie from what we last saw and in some ways an improvement.It's true of course that at the climax, the film does revert, in my view rather misguidedly, to the original. I think it would have been far better to evolve a different ending for this very different story. In the first film there was a sense that the narrow-minded hero was bound to meet his end, it was his destiny. Here in contrast it just seems unfair and somewhat arbitrary and not even entirely credible. For the the hero of this film, who has no blinkers, would have seen it coming and acted accordngly. I would submit that here is the reason people are so upset by the film. "An audience will forgive you anything at the beginning of the film and nothing at the end" as Hithcock observed. That is unfair but not entirely surprising. What is surprising is that because of the similarity of the climax few seem to have noticed just how different this film is from its model or paid any attention to its more original elements. And even more that a usually accurate journal of movie record could come up with such a slipshod review.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>Could film makers be any more inaccurate about Scottish history and culture? Wicker Man plot is complete garbage. The roman, Greek, and English propaganda of human sacrifice and barbarianism among their conquests have long been tossed aside by scholars. 		<shortDescription>How did it burn?!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"How did it burn" being the best and most memorable part of the movie. Cage's character Edward repeatedly screams it without giving Willow (Beahan) a chance to answer. My friends and I laughed and poked fun at it, just like several other parts of the movie.I'm prone to seeing bad movies. I saw Napoleon Dynamite. I saw Cold Creek Manor. I saw Lady in the Water (which I found to be not as bad as the reviews claim it is). I'd rank this above Lady in the Water but below CCM and Napoleon on the "Crappy movie" scale.First off, let's review some of the hilarity of the movie. Cage's character is apparently a druggie or something because at one point in the movie he took several pills. Those could be for his bee allergy, but drugs could easily explain his ridiculously stupid behavior throughout the movie. He sees things constantly (such as the girl that he's searching for getting hit by a truck while he's on a ship), and that would only make sense if he was either a drug addict or was mentally unstable. Another memorable (read: hilarious) part of the movie is where Edward finds the mutilated body of the pilot that was his only way out of here; his eyes ripped out and his mouth sewn shut, along with one of his hands missing. Edward immediately begins shaking the corpse as if trying to get him to "wake up." I don't think he's going to wake up now, Eddy.And then there's the ending. I didn't see this coming. Nor did I want it to happen. Sure, it's a different angle to have the main character sacrificed. It happened in The Skeleton Key (albeit the main character survived in a new body), but this time around he didn't survive. Quite the contrary; the movie draws to a close with Edward's tortured screams echoing across the theater as he burns to death. I don't like it when my protagonist dies. Especially something as horrible as being BURNT.Alright, so that's all. It had a confusing but okay plot that had several unintentionally hilarious scenes and a disturbing and disappointing ending. I haven't seen the original Wicker Man, and I doubt that the main character lives in that one. So yeah. That's my review.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2006-09-01</date>
		<username>chris_j_albanese</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Funny in surprising ways</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I never would've seen this film if Neil LaBute's name wasn't attached to it. I appreciate some of his earlier films, such as "In the Company of Men" and "Your Friends and Neighbors." "The Wicker Man" is nothing like those movies, except perhaps in that it reveals the director's understated sense of humor.I read some nutshell reviews of this film on RottenTomatoes after I had already seen it, and one of them caught my eye. It said that the result of the film was unintentionally hilarious. I agree that it was hilarious, but I certainly think LaBute appreciated the humor. For example, when Nicholas Cage was storming around the island, near the film's climax, kicking down doors, waving his gun around, beating up weird pagan women, and very much acting the part of Bruce Willis in "Die Hard", I couldn't help but laugh. His approach is just so unsubtle and inappropriate for the situation that I suspected his efforts would be futile.In the end, when Cage burns alive, LaBute might show us a lot of gore if this were a horror film. He doesn't, and it isn't. The epilogue left me smiling. I like how effortless it is for the two women in the bar. They just walk in, sit down, and immediately two men fall into their trap and their fate is sealed. The women hardly have to say a word because the men are eager to pursue them. I reckon this is a bit of observational humor from LaBute.I find the whole idea of this island of evil women who enslave and murder men to be a bit of irony on LaBute's part. He is not showing us how things are--rather, he is showing us the extreme opposite, in part at least, I am sure, for comic effect. Some viewers, I have no doubt, will find the film sexist. They will have mistaken its tone(which is rather inconsistent, and probably contributed to my opinion that this film is only slightly above average of stuff I see).</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Oh, the horror..........</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Lets face it; it was all destined to end in tears. And, as optimistic as we all tried to be, the very idea of remaking The Wicker Man was never a good one. What truly floors me, however, is that in remaking a contemporary British chiller, the producers thought it would be a a good idea to cast an American action stay in the lead role. Is this a joke? Nocholas Cage was good in Face/Off, Con Air and the like. But Jesus, stick to what you know, man! Because at the end of the day, you are not the best actor in the world.And, whilst in the original film, the lead character was a devoutly religious, unmarried virgin, in this film he is allergic to bees. Allergic. To. Bees. Wow. Thats much better. Seriously, the only thing that kept me from bursting into tears and rolling up into a foetal position on the floor was the unintentional comedy; did they honestly think people would be able to take the sight of Nicholas Cage roundhouse kicking little old ladies seriously?? Or forcing them off their bicycles at gunpoint? And whilst some might praise director/hack extraordinaire Neil LaBute for at least having the balls to keep the original ending intact, i found it simply staggering that his incompetence is of such a grand scale that he couldn't even make the sight of Nicholas Cage being burnt alive look satisfying.But in all seriousness, this film was destined to crash and burn. the plot (which has been "cleverly updated" to include the idea that the little girl who goes missing is actually his daughter) is far too out there to find acceptance amongst a mainstream audience, whilst fans of the original, and, lets face it, fans of common decency in general, will probably avoid this like a plague. Make no mistake about it though THIS IS NO HORROR MOVIE! If your looking to see a good horror flick don't waste your time go see the Grude 2 or something. 	<review>
		<date>2010-04-04</date>
		<username>Jackson Booth-Millard</username>
		<score>0.2</score>
		<shortDescription>The Wicker Man</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The original British film starring Edward Woodward and Sir Christopher Lee is a great cult classic, and naturally there came a remake by the Americans, from director Neil LaBute (In the Company of Men, Nurse Betty). Basically Edward Malus (Razzie nominated Nicolas Cage) is recovering after watching a mother and his daughter killed in a car accident, when he receives a letter from ex-fiancée Willow Woodward (Flightplan's Kate Beahan). She left him years ago, without explanation, and now she needs him, as a police officer, to help find her missing daughter Rowan (Erika-Shaye Gair), on the private and remote island of Summerisle. He explores the island of very strange people, led by Sister Summerisle (The Exorcist's Ellen Burstyn), who grow plants and keep bees for honey, and Willow reveals that Rowan isn't just her daughter, but also his. He is slowly realising that the island is overrun with women in a pagan cult, practising old rituals and preparing for some big Godforsaking celebration to improve the harvest, and sacrifice a helpless victim. He is convinced that they are all lying about the whereabouts and state of Rowan in order to kill her, but when he does eventually find her, that is when he finds out the terrifying truth. They are all in on it, including Rowan, and they are in fact going to sacrifice Edward, first breaking both his legs, stinging him with bees causing his allergic reaction, and trapping him in the wicker man to be burned alive. Also starring Frances Conroy as Dr. T.H. Moss, Molly Parker as Sister Rose / Sister Thorn, Leelee Sobieski as Sister Honey and Diane Delano as Sister Beech. Whereas the cult pagan rituals and insanity are the original film's strength, here it is one of the biggest weaknesses, it would be much more believable with Cage's character being religious like the great Woodward was. The action has been too hyped up for its own good, the mystery and menace has been dulled till the finale, and the wicker man burns much too quickly for my liking. I don't mind Cage and Burstyn too much, and tiny that don't exist in the original add tension, but all in all it was a pretty awful experience, and if you have any sense, just stick with the much more influential and superior original. It was nominated the Razzies for Worst Picture, Worst Remake or Rip-Off, Worst Screen Couple for Cage and his bear suit and Worst Screenplay. Pretty poor!</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>As always Cage puts on an excellent performance which really holds the movie together. Unlike the original wicker ma it does not contain the the religious element of the main character but only of the inhabitants of the island. A tad bit repetitive but on the whole a captivating 2 hours with brilliant performances from the majority of actors and a shocking twist at the end if your watching it for the first time. Basically it is about a group of bizarre pagan inhabitants on an island who have strange sexual rituals. When a girl goes missing on the island, cage, who is a cop in the movie, is called in by his former lover (whos girl it is), to investigate. Arriving on this island he observes the strange behaviour of its people and slowly unfolds a spine-tingling plot.</fullReview>
